text:
Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography
Authored by the Sheikh, the Muhaddith, the Allamah Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani - may Allah have mercy on him

A Word Before the Treatise

Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and no aggression except against the oppressors, and peace and blessings be upon our Prophet Muhammad, his family, and all his companions, and those who follow them in goodness until the Day of Judgment.

To proceed: Before you, O noble reader, are scientific Hadith-based research papers criticizing the book (Fiqh as-Sirah) by Dr. Muhammad Sa'id Al-Buti, a professor at the College of Sharia at the University of Damascus. He had written it for the second-year students at the college. I had published this critique in the distinguished magazine 'At-Tamaddun Al-Islami' as sequential research papers, hoping that students and others would find in them (a sound model for honest scientific criticism based on research and adherence to correct scientific rules, hoping that this would increase their care for studying the Noble Hadith scientifically, and thereby revive what has almost been obliterated of this great science due to teachers and professors limiting themselves to teaching it purely theoretically, and issuing their writings based on that for their students or others without observing even the simplest of those scientific rules regarding the selection of authentic texts and proven Hadiths from trusted sources and approved references, while attributing them to their sources and verifying them (Takhrij) with scientific precision. You see one of them - even while being a professor of this subject: Hadith - citing a Prophetic Hadith or a report related to his biography, peace and blessings be upon him, or his character, saying in its verification: 'Narrated by Abu Dawood' or 'Narrated by Ibn Hisham in (As-Sirah)', thinking that by doing so he has fulfilled the scientific trust hung around his neck and that he has advised his students. Far from it, far from it! For adhering to the scientific method referred to in Hadith studies obligates him, before this brief verification, to study the chain of transmission (Isnad) of that Hadith or report, track its narrators, and identify its defects and the statements of the specialists [A]

regarding it, then judge it according to what this study requires of authenticity or weakness, then present its summary to his students with the mentioned verification. Otherwise, such truncated verification as practiced by the referred professor is something that none of the students themselves would be incapable of, if Allah Almighty wills). That is what I had written in the introduction to my treatise (Critique of Hadith Texts in General Culture) (1) by Sheikh Muhammad Muntasir Al-Kittani, and it applies to Dr. Al-Buti completely. In fact, he exceeded the Sheikh by claiming a level of authenticity for his book (Fiqh as-Sirah) that it does not possess, as I indicated in the commentary on the mentioned introduction where I said: (Then I came across the book 'Fiqh as-Sirah' by the virtuous professor Dr. Muhammad Sa'id Ramadan Al-Buti, and I saw that he followed the path of Professor Al-Kittani, citing in it many weak and objectionable (Munkar) Hadiths, and even those with no basis at all. However, he exceeded him by stating in the introduction that he relied in it on what is authentic of Hadiths and reports. But my study of the book showed that this is a mere claim, and that his reliance was mostly on the book of the virtuous Sheikh Muhammad Al-Ghazali: 'Fiqh as-Sirah', from whom the Doctor did not limit himself to taking the name only, but went further to benefit from many of its researches and texts, and even its titles, just as he benefited from my verification (Takhrij) of it printed with it, with a disruptive abbreviation to cover up what he had done. He criticized me in three places in it, regarding which I wished - Allah bears witness - that he would be correct even in one of them, but on the contrary, he revealed by all of that that these high certificates and what they call 'Doctorate' do not give their holder knowledge, verification, or manners. I hope to have the opportunity to explain this summary, and Allah is the One sought for help).

Then the opportunity became available to me, so I explained the summary referred to in this treatise, for which the primary credit for its publication goes to the gentlemen in charge of the distinguished magazine At-Tamaddun Al-Islami, especially among them Professor Ahmad Mazhar Al-Azmah - may Allah heal and strengthen him. It was published therein sequentially in articles from issue (7 - Volume 42) to (2 - Volume 44), then I compiled it in this treatise so that the benefit may be widespread and those who could not follow it in the distinguished magazine may read it. It has been conveyed to me that some professors saw in this response of mine to the Doctor some severity and harshness at times, which they are not accustomed to in the rest of my writings and scientific responses, and they wished that it had been a purely scientific response. So I say: I firmly believe that I did nothing but what is religiously permissible for me, and that there is no way for a fair person to criticize us. How so, when Allah Almighty says in His Noble Book describing His believing servants: {And those who, when tyranny strikes them, they defend themselves... And the retribution for an evil act is an evil one like it, but whoever pardons and makes reconciliation - his reward is [due] from Allah. Indeed, He does not like wrongdoers... And whoever avenges himself after having been wronged - those have not upon them any cause [for blame]... The cause is only against the ones who wrong the people and tyrannize upon the earth without right. Those will have a painful punishment... And whoever is patient and forgives - indeed, that is of the matters [requiring] determination}. For anyone who tracks what Dr. Al-Buti writes in his books and treatises and speaks of in his sermons and gatherings will find that he never ceases to attack the Salafis in general, and me specifically without naming, and defames them among the common people and the mob, accusing them of ignorance and misguidance, and of stupidity and madness, labeling them as 'Salafiyyin' and 'Sakhfiyyin' (silly ones). Not only this, but he tries to incite the rulers against them by accusing them of being agents of colonialism, among other lies and absurdities recorded against him by Professor Muhammad Eid Abbasi in his valuable book (The Innovation of Sectarian Fanaticism) (p. 274-300) and others, supporting that by mentioning the book and page where these lies appeared. Among his calamities and fabrications is his statement in 'Fiqh as-Sirah' (p. 354 - Third Edition) after labeling them with the nickname Wahhabism: (Groups have gone astray whose hearts did not feel the love of the Messenger of Allah [C]

peace and blessings be upon him, and they went on to denounce Tawassul (seeking intercession) by his person, peace and blessings be upon him, after his death). This is as if it were a regurgitation by the Doctor of the fabrication of that unjust fanatic: (The souls of these Wahhabis are disgusted or repulsed when the name of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, is mentioned). When the Doctor utters this fabrication, he remembers that reality - of which he is aware - belies it. For the Salafis and those like them, by the grace of Allah Almighty - among all Muslims - their motto is following the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, alone to the exclusion of others, which is the definitive proof of their sincere love for him, which necessitates their love for Allah Almighty, as He said: {Say, "If you should love Allah, then follow me, [so] Allah will love you"}. Yet, the Doctor's knowledge of this divine favor upon the Salafis led his hatred against them to try to invalidate the indication of the mentioned verse regarding what preceded, and even to mislead about the Salafis anew regarding their understanding of it with this clear understanding: that following is the proof of love and is inseparable from it. So he said (p. 195 - Third Edition): (And a people have gone astray who thought that love for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, has no meaning other than following and emulating, and they missed that emulation does not come except by a restraint and a motive, and you will not find a restraint that drives one to follow except heartfelt love...). I say: The one who went astray is the one who contradicts himself; for the beginning of his speech contradicts its end. Because if nothing drives one to follow except heartfelt love - which is true, and which is what we believe and act upon - then how does this agree with the beginning of his speech which is explicit that love has a meaning other than following? If the matter were so, and the Doctor stood firm on it, he would have invalidated the indication of the Verse, and refuge is sought with Allah Almighty. On the other hand, he fabricated against us by saying: (And they missed that emulation...) etc. We absolutely did not miss that, praise be to Allah. Rather, we know with certainty that whenever a Muslim increases in following the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he increases in love for him, and whenever he increases in love for him, he increases in following him, peace and blessings be upon him. They are two matters [D]

inseparable, exactly like faith and righteous deeds. This truthful love accompanied by sincere following of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, is what the Doctor wanted to negate from the Salafis with his previous fabrication. So Allah Almighty is his reckoner, {And sufficient is Allah as a Reckoner}. That is a little of much of Dr. Al-Buti's fabrications and absurdities, for which those few people feared regarding our harshness against him at times in the response. Perhaps it has become clear to them that we were excused in that, and that we have not yet exacted our full right from him {And the retribution for an evil act is an evil one like it}, but we will not be able to exact it fully because fabrication is not permissible to be met with the like. All I have done is that I have exposed his ignorance in this science, his intrusion into it, his contradiction of the scholars, and his fabrication against them and against the innocent in a terrible manner that is almost unbelievable. Whoever wishes to get a quick idea of that, let him return to the index of this treatise to see the strange wonders. Furthermore, there is a stronger reason that necessitated the mentioned harshness in the response which those few who pity the Doctor should realize: namely, the majesty of the subject and its gravity, into which the Doctor plunged without knowledge, with arrogance and empty claims that were unprecedented. He authenticated many Hadiths and reports that no one had deemed authentic, and he weakened other Hadiths out of partisanship for the Madhhab while they are established according to the scholars of this art and field, along with his complete ignorance of Hadith terminology and the biographies of its narrators, and his turning away from benefiting from the scholars who know it. He thus opened a dangerous door for the ignorant and people of whims to authenticate whatever Hadiths they wish and weaken whatever they want. (And whoever enacts a bad precedent in Islam, upon him is its burden and the burden of those who act upon it until the Day of Resurrection). Glory be to Allah the Great! The Doctor never ceases to accuse the Salafis, among what he accuses them of, that they perform Ijtihad in Fiqh even if they are not qualified for it. Yet, here he falls into what is worse than what he accused them of, realizing the proverb: (Whoever digs a pit for his brother falls into it). Or does [E]

the Doctor see that Ijtihad in the science of Hadith by a non-Mujtahid, rather by an ignorant person, is permissible, even though all or most of Fiqh is based on this science? For this reason, I see it as a duty upon those who pity the Doctor to advise him (and Religion is Advice/Nasiha) to retract all his ignorance and fabrications, and to restrain his pen and tongue from plunging into the likes of it again, acting upon the saying of our Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him: (Help your brother, whether he is an oppressor or is oppressed. It was said: How do I help him if he is an oppressor? He said: You restrain him from oppression, for that is helping him). Narrated by Al-Bukhari from the Hadith of Anas and Muslim from the Hadith of Jabir, and it is verified in 'Al-Irwa' (2515). If the Doctor responds, that is what we hope for, and (May Allah pardon what has passed). But if it is the other way, let him blame no one but himself, and the outcome is for the righteous. Allah the Great spoke the truth when He says: {Indeed, We will support Our messengers and those who believe during the life of this world and on the Day when the witnesses will stand... The Day their excuse will not benefit the wrongdoers, and they will have the curse, and they will have the worst Home}. And may Allah send blessings and peace upon Muhammad, the unlettered Prophet, and upon his family and companions. Damascus, 27 Jumada al-Akhirah, year 1397 AH. Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani [F]

Indeed, all praise is due to Allah, we praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and the bad consequences of our deeds. Whoever Allah guides, there is no one to misguide him, and whoever He leaves astray, there is no guide for him. I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone, without partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger. To proceed: These are quick comments on the Hadiths of the book (Fiqh as-Sirah) authored by Dr. Muhammad Sa'id Ramadan Al-Buti in two parts, printed by Dar Al-Fikr Al-Hadith in Lebanon. He said in the introduction: (To proceed: These are researches in the Fiqh (jurisprudence) of the Prophetic Biography which I delivered as lectures to the first - and second - year students at the College of Sharia at the University of Damascus). I say: One of the strongest incentives for studying this book - despite the tightness of time and weak desire to read the works of contemporaries - was that I saw its virtuous author say in the introduction to the second part (p. 3): (I have followed in it the method I followed in the first part, so I isolated the researches of the Biography in the form of texts in which I relied firstly on the Sahihs (authentic books) of the Sunnah, and secondly on what is authentic of the news of the Biography in its books, and the most important of what I relied upon from that are Sirah of Ibn Hisham and Tabaqat of Ibn Sa'd). When I read this, I rejoiced and said to myself: If the news is true, then undoubtedly the Doctor, with this book of his, has opened a new door of authorship in the biography of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, which is selecting the narrations that are authentic within it from the books of Hadith and Sirah, necessitating the avoidance of mentioning what is not authentic among them according to the method of Hadith scholars and critics. This is a very important matter, for what has been written on the Noble Prophetic Biography until now numbers in the thousands [1]

as the Scholar Sayyid Sulaiman Nadwi said in his valuable book (The Muhammadan Message) (1) (p. 65). Yet, I do not know, in all that has been written of that, anyone who has taken this approach of selection that the virtuous Doctor mentioned he followed in this book. My soul has often tempted me to follow this path and compile a comprehensive book under the title (Sahih as-Sirah an-Nabawiyyah) similar to the way I proceeded in (Sahih Sunan Abi Dawood) and others which I am in the process of now, but the opportunity has not presented itself to me until this hour to perform such a duty. So when I read the Doctor's previous phrase, I thought that he had performed the duty and the hope was realized. And how could that not be a duty when his biography, peace and blessings be upon him, is but a (picture of the highest ideal in every affair of virtuous life so that it may be made a constitution to adhere to and follow. There is no doubt that whatever highest ideal one searches for in any aspect of life, he will find it all in the life of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, with the greatest clarity and perfection. Therefore, Allah made him a role model for all humanity, saying: {There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern} - Al-Ahzab 21) as the Doctor said in the introduction of his book (p. 7-8). But was the Doctor able to realize the hope, or at least restrict his reliance in the texts he quoted to what is authentic among them in the books of Sirah and the collections of Sunnah which he called (Sahihs of the Sunnah)? That is what I want to elaborate on now in this hurry, hoping from the Master, Glory be to Him and Most High, to guide our steps and inspire us with correctness and sincerity in our words and deeds.

text: 2 - The Authentic Prophetic Sunnah: It is what is contained in the books of the Imams of Hadith known for their truthfulness and trustworthiness, such as the Six Books, Muwatta of Imam Malik, and Musnad of Imam Ahmad (1). I say: What constitutes the mentioned books and others - with the exception of the Two Sahihs (Bukhari and Muslim) - is not entirely authentic Hadith. Rather, they contain the Authentic (Sahih), the Good (Hasan), and the Weak (Da'if), and in some of them, there are Fabricated (Mawdu') narrations as well, as is known to the scholars of the Noble Hadith. Some texts supporting this from what they mentioned in the (Science of Hadith Terminology) will be mentioned shortly. Therefore, the Doctor's statement regarding the Authentic Sunnah: (It is what is contained in the books of the Imams of Hadith) is an incorrect generalization. I wished to say: Perhaps it was a slip of the pen from him and that he did not intend this generality which is apparent from it and whose falsehood is known intuitively. I wished that, but I did not find in his other words nor in the methodology he practically followed what would support me in that. For his statement preceded while he was speaking about his method in the book: (I relied in it on the Sahihs of the Sunnah). So his saying (Sahihs) in the plural form instead of (The Two Sahihs and the Four Sunan) - as is the correct scientific expression - gives the impression to the researcher that the books that collect only authentic Hadiths are not limited, according to him,

He said in his book (Notes on Fiqh as-Sirah) (p. 10): (The main relied-upon sources for the Biography are limited to four sources... The Holy Quran, then the Authentic Sunnah contained in the books of Hadith whose authors are recognized for their truthfulness and trustworthiness, which are the Six Books: Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, At-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Majah, and added to them are (Al-Muwatta) by Imam Malik and (Musnad of Imam Ahmad). These books are at the highest peak of authenticity, trust, and verification. As for the other books, they contained the Sahih, the Hasan, and in some of them the Weak as well) [3].

text: to the (Two Sahihs) among the books of Sunnah. Nor can it be said: (Perhaps it was a slip of the pen from him) because I saw that he repeated this saying (Sahihs of the Sunnah) in another place in his book (Vol 1, p 15), and he means by that the Six Books. Indeed, perhaps he means with them (Al-Muwatta) and (Al-Musnad), for he coupled them with the former in this word which we are in the process of criticizing. What supports this is his previous statement: (I relied) in it firstly on the Sahihs of the Sunnah, secondly on what is authentic of the news of the Biography. This is a text from him regarding what he mentioned, because he explicitly stated that the news of the Biography contains what is not authentic, so he relied - as he claimed - on what is authentic of it. If the books of Sunnah were, in his view, like the books of Sirah in containing what is authentic and what is not authentic, he would not have needed this division and differentiation: (... Sahihs of the Sunnah) (... what is authentic of the news of the Biography). He would have said, for example: (I relied in it on what is authentic from the books of Sunnah and Sirah). So this differentiation from him is a definitive proof that he means what we mentioned: that the Authentic Sunnah is not exclusive to the (Two Sahihs) only, but the Four Sunan are also among the Sahihs of the Sunnah according to his claim. So is the matter so? That is what I will explain shortly. But to clarify the truth, I say: The Doctor is not the first to come up with such a generalization; rather, he was preceded in it. Here is the scholar Suleiman Nadwi saying in his book (The Muhammadan Message) p. 63: (And among the books classified in Hadith are the Six Sahih Books). This generalization is very common in India, and I heard it often from some of its students at the Islamic University in Madinah and from others as well. Then the virtuous Doctor followed them in that and built his book on this generalization. So is it correct? The answer: No. And here is the explanation: This generalization is pure error because it contradicts the reality in these books other than the Two Sahihs, as decided by the scholars of this science in their books. It has had dangerous effects in diverting modern authors from criticizing the Hadiths found in them under the claim that they are from the 'Sahihs'. This is what the Doctor himself fell into; we find him satisfying himself with attributing the Hadith to some of the Sunan, so there is no difference for him between a Hadith narrated by Bukhari or Muslim and another narrated by Abu Dawood or others of the authors of the Sunan, whereas the duty is to look into the Hadiths of the Sunan due to the occurrence of [4]

text: weak Hadiths in them. Imam An-Nawawi, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said in (At-Taqrib): (As for Al-Baghawi's division of the Hadiths of Al-Masabih into Hasan (Good) and Sahih (Authentic), intending by (Sahih) what is in the Two Sahihs and by (Hasan) what is in the Sunan, it is not correct, because in the Sunan there is the Sahih, the Hasan, the Da'if (Weak), and the Munkar (Objectionable)). As-Suyuti said in its explanation: (And whoever applied the term Sahih to them, like the statement of As-Silafi regarding the Five Books (meaning the Six excluding Ibn Majah): 'The scholars of the East and West agreed on their authenticity', and like Al-Hakim applying the name (Al-Jami' As-Sahih) to At-Tirmidhi, and Al-Khatib applying the name (As-Sahih) to it and to An-Nasa'i, then he has been lenient). He said in his (Alfiyyah): 'Abu Dawood narrates the strongest he found, then the weak where others were missing. And An-Nasa'i, those regarding whom they did not agree to abandon, and the others they attached. To the five, Ibn Majah, join; it is said: And whoever distinguished them, for in them is weakness. Lenient is he who applied 'Authentic' to them. And Ad-Darimi and Al-Muntaqa. And below them are Musnads, and the elevated among them is that of Ahmad and Al-Hanzali.' I say: There is no greater proof of the invalidity of this division and generalization than the fact that Tirmidhi himself explicitly stated the weakness of tens, widely hundreds, of Hadiths in his Sunan and revealed their defects. So how can it be correct to describe his book as (The Authentic Comprehensive Collection) or to judge every Hadith in it as Hasan? Something similar is said regarding Sunan Abi Dawood and Sunan An-Nasa'i, for they discuss some Hadiths at times and weaken them. As for what the scholars have weakened of the Hadiths of the two books, speak without restriction (there are many). Examples of that are very many, and whoever wishes to see a group of them should refer to our books: (Series of Weak and Fabricated Hadiths), (Takhrij Mishkat al-Masabih), and finally our book: (Critique of Hadith Texts by Sheikh Muntasir Al-Kittani). As for (Al-Muwatta) by Imam Malik, despite its majesty, it is not devoid of many Mursal (hurried) and Mu'dal (perplexing/disconnected) Hadiths, and some for which no origin was found at all, such as the Hadith (I do not forget, but [5]

book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography
text: I am made to forget) (1), and some for which an origin was found by some Hadith scholars containing both Sahih and Da'if, so verification is necessary. Therefore, As-Suyuti said in (At-Tadrib p. 4): (Al-Khatib and others stated that Al-Muwatta takes precedence over all books of Jami' and Musanids. Based on this, it is after (Sahih Al-Hakim). I counted what is in (Muwatta Malik) and what is in (Hadith of Sufyan bin Uyainah) and found in each of them over five hundred Musnad (connected) Hadiths and over three hundred Mursal Hadiths. And in it are over seventy Hadiths that Malik himself refrained from acting upon, and in them are weak Hadiths, and the majority of scholars weakened them). I say: This is the truth to which every knower of this science who has studied the Hadiths of Al-Muwatta scientifically and closely bears witness. Anything said to the contrary is rejected by the testimony of reality and correct scientific criticism. As for the Musnad of Imam Ahmad, due to the abundance of its material, weak Hadiths abound in it, and this is a matter in which there is no disagreement among the people of knowledge. Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said: (As for the existence of the weak in it, it is verified; in fact, there are fabricated Hadiths in it which I collected in a section). As-Suyuti mentioned this in his book (p. 100), then he quoted Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar refuting in his book (Al-Qawl Al-Musaddad fi Adh-Dhab 'an Al-Musnad) those who said there are fabricated Hadiths in the Musnad. I say: This is a point of disagreement and research, and Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah has a middle opinion on it which there is no need to mention now. The intent is to explain that the existence of weak Hadiths in the Musnad is a matter agreed upon among the Hadith memorizers (Huffaz). The scholar Ahmad Shakir revealed this with a precise practical disclosure in his commentary on the new Musnad in his edition, may Allah have mercy on him and reward him well.

text: 2 - His saying: (I relied in it firstly on the Sahihs of the Sunnah). I say: The error of applying this term (Sahihs of the Sunnah) to the Six Books, Al-Muwatta, and Al-Musnad, upon which the virtuous Doctor relied, has been explained previously. I want to clarify now another fact that appeared to me from my tracking of the book's Hadiths, which is: The total number of Hadiths in the book in its two parts, excluding the Hadiths of the (Two Sahihs), is eleven Hadiths. Two of them are in the first part and the rest in the other part. For Malik, there is only one Hadith, although he attributed it to Bukhari, so this spares him from attributing it to him in a book like his. For Ahmad, there are three, two of which are weak; one of them does not exist in his Musnad alongside its weakness. The rest are for the authors of the Sunan, of which two are weak: one for Tirmidhi and the other for Abu Dawood. Does this meager number relative to the size of the book, given that a third of it is weak, deserve this introduction for it with the statement: (I relied in it on the Sahihs of the Sunnah)? For anyone who reads this in the introduction imagines that the book is rich in material from the Hadiths of these books, but upon verification, he finds in it only this limited number. As for the four weak Hadiths, they are: First: He said on p. 216: (Some of the Companions said to him: O Messenger of Allah, invoke Allah against Thaqif. He said: O Allah, guide Thaqif and bring them. Narrated by Ibn Sa'd in (At-Tabaqat) and extracted by At-Tirmidhi in his Sunan, and Ibn Sa'd narrated it from Asim Al-Kinani from Al-Ashhab from Al-Hasan). The defect of the Hadith is the 'an'anah (usage of 'from' implying ambiguity) of Abu Az-Zubayr in At-Tirmidhi. I had verified it in the verification of (Fiqh as-Sirah) by Al-Ghazali (p. 432, Fourth Edition), so I will not repeat the speech on its verification. We criticize the Doctor in his verification of this Hadith on several points: [7]

book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography
text: First: His attribution of it to Ibn Sa'd after At-Tirmidhi gives the impression that it was not extracted by someone of a higher class than him and those he relied upon in his book, which is not the case, for Ahmad extracted it, but its chain is interrupted (Munqati') as I explained in the previous source. Second: He should have mentioned in his verification Tirmidhi's statement on it (Hasan Sahih) because it is stronger for his verification. Perhaps he did not mention that relying on the fact that mere attribution to Tirmidhi is sufficient to authenticate it because it is from the (Sahihs) in his view. We say this to point out the best method in verification, although I do not agree with Tirmidhi on this statement due to the aforementioned defect in its chain. Third: His saying: (Narrated by Ibn Sa'd in At-Tabaqat... and Ibn Sa'd narrated it...) is a repetitive disruption in classification, especially in a footnote which does not tolerate elongation let alone repetition. Fourth: His saying: (And Ibn Sa'd narrated it from Asim Al-Kalabi from Al-Ashhab from Al-Hasan). An error; the correct version is as in the beginning of (The Raid of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, on Ta'if) from (Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd) (2 / 159 - Beirut Edition): (And from Amr bin Asim Al-Kilabi, Abu Al-Ashhab informed us, Al-Hasan informed us). Fifth: This chain in Ibn Sa'd is not for this wording of the Hadith, but rather with the wording: (Indeed Allah did not give permission regarding Thaqif). As for the wording of the translation, it is found in his book just before this without a chain, so there is no benefit then in attributing it to him. Sixth: In the other wording, it is also weak because it is Mursal, and Mursal is from the category of Weak according to Hadith scholars, especially if it is from the Mursals of Al-Hasan, who is Al-Basri, for some Imams said regarding them: (The Mursals of Al-Hasan Al-Basri are like the wind) [8]

text: The Second Hadith: He said (p. 232): (Imam Ahmad and others narrated that two and three men used to take turns on one camel, and severe thirst afflicted them until they began to slaughter their camels to squeeze their stomachs and drink their water. Narrated by Ibn Sa'd in his Tabaqat 3 / 220). I say: First regarding it: The unrestricted attribution to Ahmad implies technically his (Musnad), and this Hadith is not in it. Therefore, Al-Haythami did not include it in (Majma' az-Zawa'id), for if it were in it, he would have included it because it fits his criteria. Al-Hafiz As-Suyuti said in (Ad-Durr Al-Manthur) (3 / 286): (And Ibn Abi Hatim, Abu Ash-Sheikh, and Al-Bayhaqi in (Ad-Dala'il) extracted from Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil (1) Abi Talib regarding the verse: {Those who followed him in the hour of difficulty} he said...) so he mentioned it. If the Hadith were in (Musnad Ahmad), he would not have left attributing it to him for attributing it to these who are below him. What makes its presence in it unlikely is that it is Mursal, for Ibn Aqil is a Tabi'i with weakness in him. Al-Hafiz said in (At-Taqrib): (Truthful, in his hadith is leniency, and it is said he changed at the end, from the fourth category). And the (Musnad) is specific to connected (Mawsul) Hadith as is known, and the Doctor imitated in this attribution the virtuous Sheikh Muhammad Al-Ghazali, for he is his predecessor in it in his book (Fiqh as-Sirah) (p. 440), from which the virtuous Doctor did not hesitate to apply this name to his book as well. The Third Hadith: He said (p. 259): (And the news of the reconciliation on Jizyah (meaning with the delegation of Najran) was narrated by Abu Dawood in the Book of Tribute, Chapter on Taking Jizyah). I say: In its chain is Asbat bin Nasr Al-Hamdani, who is weak due to his poor memory. Al-Hafiz said in (At-Taqrib): (Truthful, makes many mistakes). And from the path of Abu Dawood, Ad-Diya' Al-Maqdisi extracted it in (The Selected Hadiths Not in Sahih Al-Bukhari and Sahih Muslim) (58 / 187 / 1), so notice is required. The Fourth Hadith: He said (p. 261) mentioning the Hadith of Adi bin Hatim's conversion in detail: (Narrated by Ibn Ishaq and Imam Ahmad and Al-Baghawi in his Mu'jam with similar wordings, and see Al-Isabah by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar: 2 / 461). I say: I returned to (Al-Isabah) and saw he said: (Ahmad and Al-Baghawi in his (Mu'jam) and others narrated from the path of Abu Ubaidah bin Hudhayfah who said: I was narrating the Hadith of Adi bin Hatim, so I said: This is Adi in the district of Kufa, so I came to him and he said...) I say: so he mentioned it similar to the context of the Doctor's book and simpler than it. Then I returned to (Musnad Ahmad) and found the Hadith in it (4 / 378 and 379) from the mentioned perspective. This Abu Ubaidah was not authenticated by anyone other than Ibn Hibban, and his authentication is lenient. Therefore, Al-Hafiz did not rely on him in (At-Taqrib), saying about him: (Acceptable), meaning when corroborated, otherwise the Hadith is lenient as stated in the introduction. Since the Hadith is not known except from his path, it is weak, especially since it is in the (Sahih) abbreviated without this context as will come. As for Ibn Ishaq, he presented it (4 / 227 - Ibn Hisham) without a chain, so there is no benefit in the Doctor attributing to him because Ibn Ishaq, if he cited the Hadith with the chain to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and did not explicitly state his hearing of it from his Sheikh who narrated it from him, it would not [11]

be accepted from him because he was a Mudallis (one who conceals defects in the chain), and thus you see the verifying scholars knowledgeable in this matter finding fault with hundreds of Hadiths due to the 'an'anah (ambiguous 'from') of Ibn Ishaq and other Mudallisin. So how can his Hadith be accepted if he made it Mu'dal (omitted links) and did not cite its chain? I do not know if this was hidden from the Doctor or if he ignored it for the necessity of authorship. I have seen him do much of this kind of useless attribution, and some examples of it have passed. Yes, Al-Bukhari extracted in (Al-Manaqib) from his (Sahih) from another path from Adi the end of the Hadith similarly. What is summarized from this chapter is that correctness was not the ally of the Doctor when he applied the term: (Sahihs of the Sunnah) to other than the Two Sahihs from the aforementioned books, and that we have proven to him the weakness of four Hadiths out of eleven he attributed to them. So what would be the case if their number had reached a hundred or hundreds? There is no doubt that the percentage of weakness in them would rise in proportion to the increase in them. If this is the condition of his Hadiths which he transferred from the (Sahihs) as he claimed, then what is the condition of the other Hadiths which he transferred from the books of Sirah while indicating that there are things in these books that are not authentic and stating that he only relied on what is authentic of the news in them? That is what I want to investigate in the next chapter, Allah willing.

And if they are the rules known in the science of Noble Hadith, permit me to say to you frankly: You are between two matters: - Either you are knowledgeable of them but did not adhere to them, rather did not pay attention to them at all to see if they apply to the referred news or not? - Or you have no knowledge of them at all. I ask the readers' pardon for this frankness because I felt pained for this science, absolute pain, that someone like the Doctor would transgress against it a transgression the likes of which I do not know in what I have known. Tens of reports cannot be authentic according to scientific rules, yet he presents them to students as authentic reports. So to Allah is the complaint. Here are the reports which he attributed to some of the sources he mentioned in his previous statement explicitly and implicitly which do not have authentic chains. As for the reports which he released without attribution to anyone, I did not find great benefit in wasting time investigating them and explaining what is not authentic among them. So I say: The First Report: He said (1 / 36): (He, peace be upon him, said narrating about himself: 'I did not intend anything of what they used to do in Jahiliyyah except twice; in all of that Allah intervened between me and it. Then I did not intend it until Allah honored me with the Message. I said one night to the boy who was herding with me in upper Mecca: If you would watch my sheep for me until I enter Mecca and chat in it as the young men chat. He said: I will do so. So I went out until I was at the first house in Mecca, I heard playing (music). I said: What is this? They said: A wedding. So I sat to listen, and Allah struck my ears (with sleep) so I slept. nothing woke me except the heat of the sun... Then I said to him another night the like of that, and I entered Mecca like the first night... Then I did not intend evil after that'). [13]

Second: He said (1 / 60): (Therefore it was narrated that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said after the revelation of the verse: I do not doubt nor do I ask. Narrated by Ibn Kathir from Qatada). Thus spoke the poor Doctor: (Narrated by Ibn Kathir). Since when was Ibn Kathir a narrator? For a person to say: 'Narrated by so-and-so' means according to scholars 'with his chain of transmission'. Therefore, it is not permissible for them to say: 'Narrated by Al-Bukhari' regarding a Hadith he has without citing its chain; rather, referring to that, he says: 'Narrated by Al-Bukhari in a suspended manner (Mu'allaqan)'. So in this statement of the Doctor is an illusion for the reader who has no knowledge of Ibn Kathir's method of mentioning Hadith that he narrated it with his chain. The correct way is to say: (Ibn Kathir said: Qatada said: It reached us that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said). So he mentions it because he is the one quoted by Ibn Kathir, and there is no illusion in it; rather, it explicitly states that the Hadith reached Qatada and he did not hear it from any of the Companions, so it is Mursal, thus weak. Ibn Jarir extracted it in his (Tafsir) (11 / 116) from two paths from Qatada, so it is established from him as Mursal. Yes, it has been narrated as connected (Mawsul); Ibn Al-Mundhir, Ibn Abi Hatim, Ibn Mardawayh, and Ad-Diya' in (Al-Mukhtara) extracted it from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: {So if you are in doubt, [O Muhammad], about that which We have revealed to you, then ask those who have been reading the Scripture before you}: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not doubt and did not ask. Mentioned in (Ad-Durr Al-Manthur) (3 / 317). I say: This, despite differing somewhat from the Mursal of Qatada - for in this is a report from Ibn Abbas that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not doubt and did not ask, and in the Mursal implies that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said about himself: (I do not doubt nor do I ask). I say: With this difference in wording, I [15]

text: do not know the condition of the chain of this connected report. It is regrettable that none of the sources to which the Hadith was attributed exists in printed or manuscript form, except for (Al-Mukhtara) by Ad-Diya' Al-Maqdisi. Volumes of it in the author's handwriting, may Allah have mercy on him, are still preserved in the protected Zahiriyah Library, arranged by the Musnads of the Companions. I returned to the Musnad of Ibn Abbas in it, the number of its pages reaching about (460), and I went through all of them searching for this Hadith but did not find it, sadly. Perhaps he placed it in the margins of some pages where he used to add what he missed, writing in fine script, or in some added and lost papers. He said: What is it? I said: By Allah, I will not speak of it. He said: Then tell me: Is it something of doubt? He said: And he laughed. He said: No one was saved from that until Allah Almighty revealed (So if you are in doubt, [O Muhammad], about that which We have revealed to you, then ask those who have been reading the Scripture before you... the Verse). He said: So he said to me: If you find something in yourself, say {He is the First and the Last, the Ascendant and the Intimate, and He is, of all things, Knowing}). This, as you see, is different from the Hadith we are discussing, and I consider it very unlikely that As-Suyuti meant it in what he attributed to Ad-Diya', and Allah knows best. Third: He said (1 / 97 - 98): (The first delegation to come to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, from outside Mecca... They were some thirty men from the Christians of Abyssinia who came with Ja'far bin Abi Talib... So regarding them was revealed His saying: {Those to whom We gave the Scripture before it - they are believers in it...} Narrated by Ibn Ishaq, Muqatil, and At-Tabarani from Sa'id bin Jubayr, and see Ibn Kathir, Al-Qurtubi, and An-Nisaburi). [16]

So how did the Doctor justify asserting firstly that the verses were revealed regarding those persons when there is no authentic chain for that? And secondly, how does he attribute that to Ibn Ishaq when he doubted it and did not assert it? Is this the action of one who says: (I relied on what is authentic of the news of the Biography). Is this and that and what is coming from what is authentic... O virtuous Doctor? So to [17]

Fourth: He said (1 / 101) after mentioning the death of Khadijah and his uncle Abu Talib in the tenth year of his mission, peace and blessings be upon him: (And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, named this year the (Year of Sorrow) due to the severity of the hardships he endured in it for the sake of the Call). This is what verifying scholars do through methods of Takhrij and criticism, like Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir and others, contrary to the Doctor and his likes from the authors who are mere transporters, gatherers, and collectors. Despite asserting the authenticity of this report by saying: (And he named...), he does not at least mention its source. So from where did he know its authenticity? Therefore, this authenticity and others are merely a claim or whim from the Doctor, nothing more. What indicates this is that the only source I saw that cited it is Al-Qastallani in (Al-Mawahib Al-Ladunniyyah), mentioning nothing more than: (In what Sa'id mentioned). This Sa'id is Ibn Ubayd Al-Ijli as Az-Zarqani said in his commentary on it (1 / 244). So what is the status of this Sa'id? He is unknown, not recognized, and no one authenticated him; rather, Al-Hafiz indicated that he is lenient in Hadith if not corroborated, as is his case in this report. Moreover, Al-Qastallani's statement: (Mentioned [18]

text: by Sa'id) implies that he mentioned it suspended without a chain, so it would be Mu'dal (missing links), thus the report is weak and not authentic even if Sa'id were known for trustworthiness and memory. Far from it, far from it. Fifth: He mentioned (1 / 105 - 107) the story of his going, peace and blessings be upon him, to Ta'if, his call to Thaqif, their wounding his noble head with stones, and his supplication, peace and blessings be upon him: (O Allah, to You I complain of the weakness of my strength, the paucity of my resourcefulness, and my insignificance before people...) and his story with Addas the Christian and Addas falling upon him, peace and blessings be upon him, kissing his head, hands, and feet. He mentioned a source for it (Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd and Tahdhib as-Sirah by Ibn Hisham). I say: As for (At-Tabaqat), it did not mention of the whole story except a few letters. Even so, it is in it (1 / 211 - 212) from the statement of Muhammad bin Umar without a chain. It is highly probable that the Doctor does not know that this Ibn Umar is Al-Waqidi, the Abandoned (Matruk), as will come. As for (Tahdhib as-Sirah), he mentioned it (2 / 60) from the path of Ibn Ishaq with a Mursal chain for him, except for the supplication, for which he did not cite a chain. He said: (When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, rested, he said - according to what was mentioned to me -: O Allah...). At-Tabarani extracted the story in summary - containing the supplication - with his chain from Ibn Ishaq with his chain from Abdullah bin Ja'far. Ibn Ishaq is a Mudallis and he used 'an'anah (said 'from'), so I weakened the Hadith in (Takhrij Al-Fiqh) (p. 132). The Doctor is aware of that, so he neither benefits from such verification there nor brings what contradicts it to be looked into. Instead, he suffices with mere attribution to the two previous sources while knowing that they contain what is not authentic, then he claims that he relied on what is authentic in them. Sixth: He said (1 / 101): (Ibn Hisham says: And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered his house with dust on his head. One of his daughters stood up and began washing the dust from him while crying, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was saying to her: Do not cry, O my daughter, for Allah is the protector of your father). [19]

text: I say: Ibn Hisham extracted it in (As-Sirah) (2 / 58) from the path of Ibn Ishaq with his authentic chain from Urwah bin Az-Zubayr who said: so he mentioned it. Urwah is a Tabi'i who did not witness the incident, so it is Mursal, and Mursal is from the categories of weak Hadith according to Hadith scholars. Perhaps the Doctor knows that, so the report would not be considered authentic to him. Why then did he include it when it does not meet his condition? Or perhaps he thinks that Urwah is a Companion like his brother Abdullah bin Az-Zubayr, and that is not far from his knowledge of this noble science. From that is his prefixing it with the statement: (Ibn Hisham says), for this is only said by scholars regarding what is suspended without a chain, as I will explain in the next Hadith. The reality here is that Ibn Hisham mentioned his chain as you saw, so the mentioned prefix is a clear error. The correct phrasing is: (Ibn Hisham narrated). And Ibn Sa'd narrated likewise. The Seventh Hadith: He said (1 / 124): (Ibn Sa'd says in his Tabaqat Vol 1 p 200 and 201: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to attend the season every year following the pilgrims... and saying: O people, say there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah, you will succeed, you will possess the Arabs, and the non-Arabs will submit to you, and if you believe, you will be kings in Paradise. And Abu Lahab was behind him saying: Do not obey him...). I say: First regarding it: His prefixing this Hadith with the statement (Ibn Sa'd says) implies in the terminology of Hadith scholars that it is a suspended (Mu'allaq) Hadith in Ibn Sa'd, meaning he did not cite its chain, but the matter is not so as will come. It is known among scholars that in Sahih Al-Bukhari there are many suspended Hadiths from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, or some of his Companions. If a student of knowledge wants to quote something from these Hadiths, he does not say in them: (Al-Bukhari narrated) because this expression is specific to connected Hadiths. Rather, he says indicating that: (Al-Bukhari said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said... or The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was...). He does not say in this genre (Al-Bukhari narrated) as we mentioned unless he qualifies that by saying (Al-Bukhari narrated suspendedly). Just as he does not say in the connected genre of Hadiths 'Al-Bukhari said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said' because it implies it is from the suspended ones in his book. This is what the virtuous Doctor fell into by prefixing [20]

text: the Hadith with the mentioned statement, thus giving an impression contrary to reality, either due to lack of knowledge of the difference between the expressions (Said) and (Narrated) or due to his negligence in expression. Second: The Hadith in Ibn Sa'd is from the path of his Sheikh Muhammad bin Umar, saying: Muhammad bin Umar informed us, saying: Ayyub bin An-Nu'man told me... so he mentioned several chains for it, all of them Mursal. My thought is that the Doctor does not know that this Muhammad bin Umar is Al-Waqidi, and if he knows that, my thought is that he does not know anything of his biography according to Hadith scholars. Therefore, I quote the testimony of two famous Hadith memorizers. Imam Adh-Dhahabi said in his book (Ad-Du'afa' wal-Matrukin - The Weak and Abandoned Narrators): (Muhammad bin Umar bin Waqid Al-Waqidi; An-Nasa'i said: He fabricates Hadith. Ibn Adi said: His Hadiths are not preserved, and the calamity comes from him). The Sixteenth Hadith (2 / 68): (Ibn Hisham narrated that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to his companions: Who is the man who will look for me what Sa'd bin Ar-Rabi' did? The Seventeenth Hadith He said (2 / 174): (And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to them: The commander of the people is Zayd bin Harithah, if he is killed then Ja'far bin Abi Talib, if he is killed then Abdullah bin Rawahah, if he is killed then let the Muslims choose a man and make him over them. indicated by numbers in my verification of (Fiqh as-Sirah by Al-Ghazali) (p. 396). The Doctor is aware of it and has benefited from it and its original as previously indicated. Therefore, we see that the Doctor and his likes must imitate the specialists and knowledgeable ones in that from Hadith scholars and limit themselves to quoting their statements in authentication and weakening. If they do not do so, they go astray and lead others astray, and many examples witnessing to what we said have passed. This is one thing, and another thing is that the Hadith in Ibn Sa'd (2 / 128 Beirut Edition) is without a chain, so how can the non-existent be judged as authentic? Yes, I have known Ibn Sa'd's basis in that, which is his Sheikh Al-Waqidi, for Ibn Kathir said in (Al-Bidayah) (4 / 241): (And Al-Waqidi said: Rabi'ah bin Uthman told me...) so he mentioned it. So if the Doctor were researching as scholars research, especially since he presented that huge introduction: (I relied on what is authentic of the news of the Biography in its books) and was capable and eager to fulfill what he said, he would not have hastened to rely on Ibn Sa'd's suspended narration without a chain, especially when its end contains what alerts

That is his saying (2 / 129): (When the people of Medina heard of the army of Mu'tah arriving, they met them at (Al-Jurf). The people began throwing dust in their faces and saying: 'O Runaways (Furrar)! Did you flee from the path of Allah?' So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'They are not runaways, but they are those who return to fight (Karrar), if Allah wills.') I said: This is Munkar (objectionable), nay, false and clearly invalid. For how is it conceivable that the victorious army, despite their small number and equipment against the Roman army which was superior to them in numbers and equipment by many fold—how is it conceivable that these believing people would be met with dust thrown in their faces and accused of fleeing from Jihad, when they did not flee? Rather, they stood firm with the firmness of heroes until Allah granted them victory and opened for them, as in the Hadith of Al-Bukhari: (...until a sword from the swords of Allah took the banner, until Allah granted them victory)? Among the wonders is that the Doctor, after mentioning this authentic Hadith and following it with his saying: (And this Hadith indicates, as you see, that Allah supported the Muslims with victory in the end), he nevertheless cited this objectionable addition and said (2 / 180): (As for the reason the people said to the Muslims after their return to Medina: 'O Runaways'... it is because they did not pursue the Romans and those with them in their defeat...) text: So you see that this Hadith is other than the Hadith of the chapter. If this attribution to Ibn Sa'd by the Doctor the second time was not due to an illusion from him, then it is one of the many proofs that he does not master the craft of Takhrij [extraction] at all. For it is not permissible to say: 'Ibn Sa'd narrated from Al-Hasan from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: (O Allah, guide Thaqif and bring them),' because Al-Hasan did not narrate that in Ibn Sa'd. Anyone who comes across this Takhrij by the Doctor would understand the opposite! It is most likely that this was only intentional on his part, so it is proof of what I mentioned. Because I saw him later, when I extracted a Hadith of Ibn Abbas and attributed it to Ahmad and Ibn Majah, he critiqued me saying it is in the (Two Sahihs) and expressed amazement at my failure to attribute the Hadith to them. Yet, if that attribution had come from me - and I ask Allah to protect me from the like - it would have been a sheer error like this error of the Doctor in attributing this Hadith to the narration of Ibn Sa'd from Al-Hasan. The detailed discussion on that will come in its place, Allah willing. Hadith Twenty-One: He said (2 / 246 - 247) in the Takhrij of the story of Masjid Al-Dirar: (Tafsir Ibn Kathir 2 / 387 - 388, and Ibn Hisham narrated it in his Seerah in a similar manner in Vol 2 / 322). I said: Firstly: The Takhrij does not imply - like many of his Takhrijs - that the story is authentic. For in Ibn Hisham, it is via Ibn Ishaq without a chain, and in Ibn Kathir, it is from his path via a group I mentioned in (Takhrij Al-Fiqh) (p. 488). Secondly: The Doctor abbreviated this Takhrij from our mentioned Takhrij, and what he mentioned is almost copied from it word for word, except that he deleted from it our statement at the beginning that it is (Weak). So what drove the Doctor to this deletion and failure to mention the source from which he took his Takhrij? If his fear that people might say: 'The Doctor benefited from Al-Albani's Takhrij' allows him that, does it allow him to delete the ruling of weakness which [35]

Let him know that Allah the Exalted will question him and hold him accountable for what he has done in this book of authenticating reports that are not authentic, neither out of his following (Taqlid) of the people of knowledge, nor out of his own independent reasoning (Ijtihad), because he is not among the people of Ijtihad - by his own admission - in Fiqh, in which the Doctor holds a degree, let alone in this noble science whose scent he has not yet smelled. Hadith Twenty-Two: He said (2 / 250) regarding the story of the delegation of Thaqif: (Ibn Sa'd narrated that he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to come to them every night after Isha, standing over them speaking to them until he would alternate [his weight] between his feet). I said regarding it are criticisms: First: That Ibn Sa'd did not cite its chain, so how did he know its authenticity and rely upon it? Second: That limiting the attribution to him gives the student the impression that it was not narrated by one who is more famous than him and more worthy of reliance, and that is not the case. For Abu Dawud extracted it in (Qiyam Ramadan) and Ibn Majah at the end of (Iqamat as-Salat), both from the Hadith of Aws bin Hudhayfah, and Ahmad also (4 / 343) without the alternating [of feet]. Third: That its chain is not authentic because it is from the narration of Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman bin Ya'la Al-Ta'ifi from Uthman bin Abdullah bin Aws Al-Ta'ifi, and this one was not declared trustworthy by anyone except Ibn Hibban, but a group of trustworthy narrators narrated from him; however, the first one [Abdullah] was weakened by Al-Dhahabi and Al-Asqalani, so he is the defect of the Hadith. Hadith Twenty-Three: He said (2 / 251) regarding the story of the delegation of Thaqif also: (Ibn Ishaq said: And they also asked him to remove the prayer from them. So he said to them: There is no good in a religion with no prayer.) I said: The completion of this narration in Ibn Ishaq in (Al-Seerah) (4 / 183 - 185) is: (They said: O Muhammad, then we will grant it to you, even if it is a humiliation.) [36]

I said: This is not authentic like the previous Hadiths, because it is with him via a Mu'dal [interrupted] chain. As for the Marfu' [elevated to Prophet] part of it, Abu Dawud and Ahmad extracted it with a Munqati' [broken] chain as I clarified in (Takhrij Al-Fiqh) (p. 540). Yet the Doctor ignored this like others - from what preceded - and authenticated it. So Allah is the One sought for help. Twenty-Fourth: He said in (The Farewell Pilgrimage) (2 / 270): (When he, peace and blessings be upon him, saw the House, he said: 'O Allah, increase this House in honor, magnification, nobility, and awe, and increase him who magnifies it among those who perform Hajj or Umrah to it in honor, nobility, awe, respect, and righteousness.' Narrated by Al-Tabarani and Ibn Sa'd). I said: This is very weak, indeed fabricated. As for Ibn Sa'd, he mentioned it without a chain (2 / 173). As for Al-Tabarani, he extracted it in (Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir) (Vol 1, Folio 149 / 2 manuscript) from Hudhayfah bin Asid, and in its chain is Asim bin Sulayman Al-Kuzi. Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (Ibn Adi said: He is counted among those who fabricate Hadith. Al-Fallas said: He used to fabricate; I have never seen the likes of him... And Al-Daraqutni said: A liar). Al-Haythami said in (Majma' Al-Zawa'id) (3 / 238) after attributing it to Al-Tabarani: (He is Matruk [abandoned]). I said: Based on this, two matters apply to the Doctor, one of which must be true: First: If he knew this defect and yet decisively attributed it to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, then he is included in the threat of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Whoever narrates a Hadith from me seeing that it is a lie, then he is one of the liars). Extracted by Muslim in the introduction to his (Sahih) (1 / 7) via two authentic chains from Samurah bin Jundub and Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah. And the other: If he did not know it - which is the assumption about him - then how did he narrate it and speak with it while the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, says: (It is enough of a lie for a man to narrate everything he hears)? Also extracted by Muslim (1 / 8) via an authentic chain. Rather, how did he include it in his book in which he claimed [37]

that he relied on authentic reports? It is also assumed that he has no knowledge of these two Hadiths, otherwise they would have been sufficient to deter him from narrating weak Hadiths under the guise that they are authentic? And Allah is the One sought for help, and to Allah we belong and to Him we return. With this ends what I wanted to mention of the weak Hadiths and flimsy reports that I stumbled upon in Doctor Al-Buti's book. They clarify most clearly that what he said in the texts of his book (I relied in them firstly on the authentic collections of Sunnah. Secondly, on what is authentic of the reports of Seerah in its books) (1) was nothing but mere publicity for the book and to draw people's attention to it. Within the folds of the discussion on them, it is clear that he does not possess the culture and knowledge of the Sunnah, the terminology of Hadith, and the biographies of narrators that would enable him to implement this methodology which he claimed to have adopted in his book, even by relying on scholars for that and imitating them. For he does not even master imitating them because he has no knowledge of their statements. Yet, he attempts to do the work of the stalwarts among them, but far from it. How similar he is to the saying of some of the predecessors: (You are but like the chick; it hears the roosters crowing, so it crows with them). There remain with me other examples of his errors which indicate the extent of his knowledge of this noble art, and they represent various types of distance from the correct scientific approach. So I say:

book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography
text: 1 - He said (1 / 31): (The narrators of the Seerah have agreed that the Bedouin lands of Bani Sa'd bin Bakr were suffering at that time from a drought year wherein the udders had dried and the crops withered. But no sooner had Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, come into Halimah's home and settled in her lap and [drank from] her breast, than the dwellings of Halimah around her tent became fertile and green...)
foot_note: 1. (1) He confirmed that in the introduction to the third edition with his saying: (And I know that I have not recorded in this book of mine any events of the Seerah except the most important and most authentic of them). So did he tell the truth? [38].

I said: We have two criticisms against him: First: The mentioned consensus was not claimed by anyone before the Doctor as far as I know, so it has no value. The other: The story did not come with a chain of narration that establishes proof. Its most famous path is what Muhammad bin Ishaq narrated from Jahm bin Abi Jahm from Abdullah bin Ja'far from Halimah bint Al-Harith As-Sa'diyah. Abu Ya'la extracted it (Folio 128 / 1) and from him Ibn Hibban (2094 - Mawarid), and Abu Nu'aym in (Dala'il An-Nubuwwah) (1 / 47) from Ibn Ishaq with it. Al-Bayhaqi extracted it in (Dala'il An-Nubuwwah) (1 / 108) from him also, except that he said: Jahm bin Abi Al-Jahm - a freed slave of a woman from Bani Tamim who was with Al-Harith bin Hatib, and he used to be called: the freed slave of Al-Harith bin Hatib - told us, he said: Anyone who heard Abdullah bin Ja'far bin Abi Talib told us, saying: I was told from Halimah bint Al-Harith. I said: This is a weak chain containing two defects: First: The disruption (Idtirab) in its chain as is apparent. In the first narration, there is the 'an'ana [saying 'from'] of Ibn Ishaq from all his narrators. In the other, his declaration of hearing (Tahdith) along with Jahm's declaration that he did not hear it from Abdullah bin Ja'far, and the latter's declaration that he did not hear it from Halimah. So according to the first narration, there is a disconnection between Ibn Ishaq and Jahm because the former is famous for Tadlis (obfuscation). And according to the other narration, the disconnection is in two places in it. From this, you learn the illusion of Al-Hafiz in (Al-Isabah) where he said (4 / 266): (Ibn Hibban declared the hearing [Tahdith] between Abdullah and Halimah in his Sahih). For there is no basis for this Tahdith in Ibn Hibban nor in others we mentioned. And it is very unlikely that Abdullah bin Ja'far met Halimah, the wet nurse of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, for when the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, died, Abdullah was ten years old. Even if they did not mention a date of death for her, it is usually assumed that she died before the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. Allah knows best. [39]

Whether the first narration or the other is more correct, the chain is disconnected inevitably. The other defect is that it pivots on Jahm bin Abi Al-Jahm, who is of unknown status (Majhul Al-Hal). Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (The story of Halimah As-Sa'diyah is not known from him). As for Ibn Hibban, he mentioned him in (Al-Thiqat) (1 / 31) according to his rule in declaring unknowns trustworthy. The story has two other paths in Abu Nu'aym pivoting on Al-Waqidi, who is a liar. One of them is from his Sheikh Musa bin Shaybah, who is lenient (Layyin) in Hadith as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib). The other is from Abdul Samad bin Muhammad As-Sa'di from his father from his grandfather, who said: Some of those who used to herd Halimah's sheep told me... and these are unknowns.

book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography
text: 2 - He said (1 / 55): (The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, grieved due to that a great grief, to the point that he was attempting - as Imam Al-Bukhari narrates - to throw himself from the peaks of the mountains.) I said: This attribution to Al-Bukhari is a gross error. That is because it gives the illusion that this story of throwing oneself down is authentic according to Al-Bukhari's condition, which is not the case. The explanation is that Al-Bukhari extracted it at the end of Aisha's Hadith on the beginning of revelation, which the Doctor cited (1 / 51 - 53). It is in Al-Bukhari at the beginning of (Interpretation of Dreams) (12 / 297 - 304 Fath) via Ma'mar: Al-Zuhri said: So Urwah informed me from Aisha... and he cited the Hadith up to his saying: (And the revelation paused). And Al-Zuhri added: (Until the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, became sad - according to what has reached us - a sadness due to which he went early several times to throw himself from the tops of the mountain peaks. Whenever he reached the peak of a mountain to throw himself from it, Gabriel appeared to him [40]

book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography
text:
and said: 'O Muhammad, you are truly the Messenger of Allah.' So his agitation would calm down and his soul would settle, and he would return. If the pause in revelation became long for him, he would go early for the like of that. If he reached the peak of a mountain, Gabriel would appear to him and say the like of that to him.) Thus Ahmad (6 / 232 - 233), Abu Nu'aym in (Ad-Dala'il) (p. 68 - 69), and Al-Bayhaqi in (Ad-Dala'il) (1 / 393 - 395) extracted it with this addition via Abdur Razzaq from Ma'mar with it. From this path, Muslim extracted it (1 / 98), but he did not cite its wording; rather, he referred it to the wording of the narration of Yunus from Ibn Shihab, which does not contain the addition. Likewise, Muslim and Ahmad (6 / 223) extracted it via Uqayl bin Khalid: Ibn Shihab said... with it, without the addition. And likewise, Al-Bukhari extracted it at the beginning of the Sahih from Uqayl with it. I said: We conclude from the above that this addition has two defects: First: Ma'mar's solitude in narrating it without Yunus and Uqayl, so it is Shadh (anomalous). Second: It is Mursal Mu'dal (hurried/interrupted/perplexing), for the one saying: (according to what has reached us) is Al-Zuhri, as is apparent from the context. Al-Hafiz decided on this in (Al-Fath) (12 / 302) and said: (It is from the Balaghat [reports reaching someone] of Al-Zuhri and is not connected). I said: This is what the Doctor neglected or was ignorant of, so he thought that every letter in (Sahih Al-Bukhari) is according to his condition of authenticity. Perhaps he does not distinguish between the Musnad (connected) Hadith in it and the Mu'allaq (suspended), just as he did not distinguish between the connected Hadith in it and the Mursal Hadith that came in it incidentally, like this Hadith of Aisha, at the end of which came this Mursal addition. Know that this addition did not come through a connected path that can be used as proof, as I clarified in (Silsilat Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah) number (4858), and I pointed that out in the commentary on (My Abridgment of Sahih Al-Bukhari) (1 / 5), may Allah facilitate the completion of its printing. [41]

If you know the lack of establishment of this addition, we have the right to say that it is an objectionable addition in terms of meaning, because it does not befit the infallible Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to attempt to kill himself by throwing himself from the mountain, whatever the motive for him to do so, while he is the one who said: (Whoever throws himself from a mountain and kills himself, he will be in the Fire of Hell throwing himself down in it, abiding eternally therein forever). Extracted by the two Sheikhs and others, and I extracted it in (Takhrij Al-Halal wa Al-Haram) number (447).

3 - He said (1 / 115): (Before the legislation of prayer, he, peace be upon him, used to pray two rak'ahs in the morning and two like them in the evening, as Ibrahim, peace be upon him, used to do). I say: I do not know a chain of narration for this Hadith. If the Doctor has come across it, let him mention its source to us so we can study it, and I do not think it is authentic. Yes, Ibn Sayyid An-Nas mentioned in (Uyun Al-Athar) (1 / 91) from Muqatil bin Sulayman: (Allah obligated prayer at the beginning of Islam as two rak'ahs in the morning and two rak'ahs in the evening, then He obligated the five on the Night of Ascension). Then he mentioned similar from Al-Harbi (1 / 149) and quoted Ibn Abd Al-Barr saying: (This is not found in an authentic report). Then Ibn Sayyid An-Nas pointed out (1 / 152) the weakness of Al-Harbi's statement. I said: Muqatil bin Sulayman is Matruk (abandoned), severely weak. Al-Hafiz said: (They declared him a liar and abandoned him, and he was accused of Tajsim [anthropomorphism]).

book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography

4 - He said (p. 147): (No one among the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, migrated except in hiding, other than Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. For Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated that when he [Umar] intended to migrate, he girded his sword, slung his bow, and held arrows in his hand (and in it that he said:) ('Whoever wishes his mother to be bereft of him, or his child to be orphaned, or his wife to be widowed, let him meet me behind this [42]

valley'). Ali said: So no one followed him except a group of the weak; he taught them and guided them, then proceeded on his way. Usd Al-Ghabah Vol 4 p 58). I said: There are two criticisms against him: First: His saying: (No one migrated...) What is the basis for this negation? For the narration he mentioned from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, contains nothing of that. If the Doctor's basis for it is only that it was not known except about Umar, then the answer is that scholars say: Lack of knowledge of a thing does not necessitate knowledge of its non-existence. This is if the negation comes from people of knowledge, so how about when it is from someone like Doctor Al-Buti? Second: His assertion that Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, migrated openly, relying on the mentioned narration of Ali, and his assertion that Ali narrated it, is not correct. Because the chain of narration for it to him is not authentic. The author of (Usd Al-Ghabah) did not first assert its attribution to him, may Allah be pleased with him, and secondly, he cited his chain for it to him so that his responsibility would be cleared and so that those of knowledge could look into it. I found it pivots on Al-Zubayr bin Muhammad bin Khalid Al-Uthmani: Abdullah bin Al-Qasim Al-Amali (thus in the original, perhaps Al-Ayli) told us from his father with his chain to Ali. These three are among the unknowns (Majahil), for none of the people of Jarh and Ta'dil mentioned them at all. Did the Doctor find them and know their probity and accuracy so that he permitted himself to assert the authenticity of the narration from Ali? Or is his affair in it like his affair in others, merely a gatherer of firewood [at night], or as the common people say here in the Levant: (Khabt Laz' - Slap and Stick)? Then, in addition to that, he claims that he relied on authentic narrations.

5 - He said: (2 / 12): (So (Umar) said: 'Shelter the people from the rain, and beware [that] (1) you paint it red or yellow, thereby tempting the people.' I'lam As-Sajid 337). I said: This report was narrated by Al-Bukhari in (Chapter: Building of the Mosque) from

his (Sahih) as Mu'allaq Majzum [suspended definitively] (1). So the Doctor leaving the attribution to it, despite it indicating authenticity, for attributing it to (Al-I'lam) which does not indicate authenticity, is a negligence not forgiven from the likes of him if he were of the people of knowledge of Hadith. For it is known among them that it is not appropriate to attribute a Hadith that is in the (Two Sahihs) or one of them to the four Sunan, let alone those below them. So how is it permissible to attribute it to someone who is below them all, like Al-Zarkashi the author of (I'lam As-Sajid)? Mughlatay said: (A traditionist has no right to attribute a Hadith in one of the Six [Books] to other than them except for an addition not present in them or to clarify its chain and narrators). Al-Munawi quoted it in (Fayd Al-Qadir) (1 / 280).

text: 6 - He said (2 / 69): (As for what was narrated that he, peace be upon him, prayed over them (meaning the martyrs of Uhud) ten by ten, and in every ten was Hamzah, until he prayed over him seventy times: it is weak and an error. Refer to Mughni Al-Muhtaj 1 / 399). I said: This is a new type of the Doctor's mix-ups. He was not satisfied with types of errors we uncovered previously, especially those regarding weak Hadiths he authenticated, until he now came with a new style of error, which is weakening authentic reports. For this Hadith has many paths, and some are Hasan. Al-Hafiz Al-Zayla'i cited a large portion of them in (Nasb Ar-Rayah) (2 / 309 - 313), and likewise Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani in (Ad-Dirayah) (1 / 243 - 244) and (Talkhis Al-Habir) (1 / 11), and he leaned towards strengthening it. This is what no traditionist who came across those paths can oppose. Therefore, I cited it in my separate book: (Ahkam Al-Jana'iz wa Bida'uha) Issue (70). Moreover, regarding the prayer over Hamzah and other martyrs, there are other Hadiths, some of which are authentic, which I mentioned in Issues (22 and 60) of the mentioned book.

book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography
text: The intelligent reader might be struck by the Doctor's weakening of this Hadith, contrary to his habit and for the first time in his book, so he asks about the reason for that? So I say: Since the Doctor is Shafi'i in Madhhab and fanatical about it, as indicated by his treatment of some Fiqh issues in this book, and the Hadith stipulates the legitimacy of praying over martyrs while his Madhhab states the lack of its legitimacy (1), therefore he weakened it, not because the scientific Hadith methodology necessitates its weakness. How so, when Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar strengthened it, and he is Shafi'i in Madhhab as well, as is known? Also striking is the Doctor's reference in weakening the Hadith to the book (Mughni Al-Muhtaj), for this is a book of Fiqh. It is known among people of knowledge that in every science one must refer to the specialists in it. Why did the Doctor not refer to a reliable book of Hadith like those mentioned just now? Would the Doctor be satisfied if someone referred him in a Fiqh issue to a book of Hadith like the Sunan and others? Yes, if the author of (Mughni Al-Muhtaj), who is Sheikh Muhammad Ash-Shirbini Al-Khatib (2), was known for his engagement with the science of Hadith and his verification in it - in addition to his knowledge of Shafi'i Fiqh - the mentioned reference would be somewhat acceptable. But he was not known for any of that at all. In fact, his mentioned book clearly indicates that he is very far from this noble science, farther than others from it, indeed perhaps he is a predecessor to him in that. Look at him, for example, saying (1 / 5): (And in (Al-Ihya) that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: A little success (Tawfiq) is better than a lot of knowledge. And in some narrations (Intellect instead of Knowledge). So when was Al-Ghazali's book (Al-Ihya) a reference for people of knowledge in Hadith, while it is
