known among beginners in this science as being packed with weak and fabricated Hadiths and what has no basis in Hadith? Including this very Hadith, for Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said in his (Takhrij) (1 / 38): (I did not find a basis for it). And he says (1 / 13): (And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, used to stop when he reached Adnan in lineage, then say: The genealogists have lied). I said: This is a fabricated Hadith as I clarified in (Silsilat Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah wal-Mawdu'ah) number (111). And his saying (1 / 45) regarding the Hadith of the Two Sheikhs: (If one of you cleans himself with stones, let him do so with an odd number): (And the narration of Abu Dawud diverted it from obligation, which is his saying, peace be upon him: Whoever cleans himself with stones, let him make it odd; whoever does so has done well, and whoever does not, there is no sin). This is a weak narration not suitable for the mentioned diversion; Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Asqalani weakened it as I clarified in my book (Da'if Sunan Abi Dawud) number (8). And his saying (1 / 512): (Al-Bukhari narrated: Whoever prays upon me at my grave, Allah appoints an angel to convey it to me, and his worldly and otherworldly affairs are sufficed, and I will be a intercessor or witness for him on the Day of Resurrection). Attributing this to Al-Bukhari is a gross error, for it is a fabricated Hadith as I clarified in the mentioned Silsilah: number (203). Perhaps he saw it attributed to Ibn An-Najjar and thought it distorted from Al-Bukhari, so he attributed it to him due to his poor judgment and lack of knowledge that among the traditionists is one known as (Ibn An-Najjar), the author of (Tarikh Al-Madinah) known as (Ad-Durar Ath-Thaminah), for he extracted the first part of it from him. Then Ash-Shirbini mentioned lines later the Hadith (Whoever performs Hajj and does not visit me has shunned me) and said: Ibn Adi narrated it in (Al-Kamil) and others. Then he said: (This indicates that it is emphasized for the pilgrim more than others). I said: Yes, indeed it indicates that visiting him, peace be upon him, is obligatory because shunning him, peace be upon him, is a sin and leaving it is obligatory [to avoid]. But we say to him and his likes: Establish the throne then engrave. For the mentioned Hadith is fabricated by the testimony of critical Imams like [46]

Ibn Al-Jawzi, As-Saghani, Az-Zarkashi, Adh-Dhahabi and others, as we clarified in (Silsilat Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah wal-Mawdu'ah) (45). Al-Hafiz Ibn Abd Al-Hadi elaborated on it in (As-Sarim Al-Munki) (p. 75 - 80) and concluded by saying: (The result: This Hadith cannot be used as proof and cannot be relied upon except by one whose heart Allah has blinded and is among the most ignorant of people in the science of transmitted reports). Then he mentioned on the same page the Hadith of Adam's Tawassul by the Prophet, peace be upon him, which is also fabricated as Al-Hafiz Adh-Dhahabi and others said, and I have spoken about it in the Silsilah referred to just now under number (25) (1). To other than that of many examples which if tracked would make a huge volume. This is the state of the author of (Mughni Al-Muhtaj) whom Doctor Al-Buti referred to for knowing the weakness of the mentioned Hadith. From it, the intelligent person knows the state of the one referring to him in this noble science.

book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and the Sirah
text:
7 - He said (2 / 172): “It is narrated from Anas رضي الله عنه that the Prophet صلى الله عليه وسلم wrote to Khosrow, and to Caesar, and to the Negus, and to every tyrant, calling them to Allah the Exalted.” I (the author) say: The hadith is in Sahih Muslim (6 / 166). So beginning it with the wording ‘It is narrated’ (ruwiya) suggests that, in his view, the hadith is weak, or that he does not know its authenticity, or that he is unaware that this form and others similar to it—forms constructed in the passive—are used by hadith scholars specifically for weak hadith. And that it is not permissible to introduce an authentic hadith with such wording. These are three possibilities, and one of them must apply to the doctor. Perhaps the last one fits him best, for he is from the general public who do not care to abide by the rules of the hadith scholars—as Imam An-Nawawi رحمه الله pointed out. And this is assuming the doctor even knows these rules. An-Nawawi said in the introduction to his great work *Al-Majmū‘ Sharh al-Muhadhdhab* (1 / 63): “The verifying scholars from among the people of hadith and others have said: If the hadith is weak…” [47]

It is not said in it: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said, or did, or commanded, or forbade, or judged,' and similar forms of certainty (Jazm). Likewise, it is not said: 'Abu Hurairah narrated, or said, or mentioned, or informed, or told, or transmitted, or gave a fatwa,' and the like. Similarly, this is not said regarding the Tabi'in and those after them regarding what is weak. Thus, none of that is spoken of with the form of certainty. Rather, in all of this, it is said: 'It was narrated from him, or it was transmitted from him, or it was told about him, or it reached us from him,' or it is said: 'It is said, or it is mentioned, or it is told, or it is narrated, or it is elevated (Marfu'), or it is attributed,' and similar forms of passivity/uncertainty (Tamrid), and these are not forms of certainty. They said: Forms of certainty are designated for the Authentic (Sahih) or Good (Hasan), and forms of uncertainty for what is other than them. This is because the form of certainty implies its authenticity from the one it is attributed to, so it should not be applied except to what is authentic; otherwise, the person would be in the sense of lying against him, peace and blessings be upon him. This etiquette was violated by the author and the majority of jurists from our companions and others, indeed the majority of scholars of sciences absolutely, except for the skilled Hadith scholars. That is an ugly leniency, for they often say in the (Authentic): 'It was narrated from him,' and in the (Weak): 'So-and-so said and narrated,' and this is a deviation from correctness). I say: The Doctor has fallen into both uglinesses. In this authentic Hadith, he said: 'It was narrated,' and in those weak Hadiths, despite their abundance, he did not preface a single one of them with the form of uncertainty, but rather with the form of certainty.

text: 8 - He said (3 / 181), mentioning the story of Banu Bakr attacking Khuza'ah at night and the departure of Amr bin Salim Al-Khuza'i with forty riders from Khuza'ah, coming to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, informing him of what befell them. He said: (So he stood up dragging his garment saying: 'I would not be supported if I do not support Banu Ka'b regarding what I support myself from'). I say: In this extraction (Takhrij) and attribution are errors (Wahm) that should be clarified: First: The story is not among (what is authentic of the news of the Biography) because it is with this text in Ibn Sa'd (2 / 134) and Ibn Ishaq (4 / 32 - 37) without a chain of transmission (Isnad), so how can it be judged as authentic? Second: This text was not narrated by Al-Bazzar at all, so attributing it to him and claiming that Ibn Hajar attributed it to him is a double error. For his [Ibn Hajar's] words are explicit in other than what the Doctor attributed to him. He mentioned the story from the path of Ibn Ishaq, and in it is that when the Khuza'i man came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was sitting in the mosque, he said: 'O Lord, I appeal to Muhammad, the alliance of our father and his father the old one...' etc., the verses. So Al-Hafiz said (7 / 419): (Al-Bazzar narrated from the path of Hammad bin Salamah from Muhammad bin Amr from Abu Salamah from Abu Hurairah *some of the verses mentioned in this story*, and it is a good (Hasan) connected chain. But Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated it from Yazid bin Harun from Muhammad bin Amr from Abu Salamah as Mursal (disconnected). And he also extracted it from the narration of Ayyub from Ikrimah as Mursal at length... And Abdur-Razzaq extracted it from the path of Miqsam from Ibn Abbas at length without the poetry. And At-Tabarani extracted it from the Hadith of Maymunah bint Al-Harith at length... And in Musa bin Uqbah regarding this story: He said: 'It is mentioned that...') I say: It is clear from Al-Hafiz's words that Al-Bazzar did not narrate the story, but rather narrated some verses from it, so attributing it to him is a clear error. And At-Tabarani's chain is weak as I mentioned in (Takhrij Al-Fiqh) (p. 404). However, it appears from the sum of its paths that it has a basis in general. Verification requires tracking the wordings of these paths, so whatever they agree upon is established. This requires accessing some of the sources mentioned by Al-Hafiz, such as the book of Ibn Abi Shaybah and Abdur-Razzaq, which is not feasible now [49]

Third: It became clear from Al-Hafiz's words which I mentioned just now that Musa bin Uqbah did not cite the Hadith with a chain of transmission, but rather suspended it by saying: (It is mentioned). So the Doctor's statement that Al-Hafiz said, conjoining with Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani: (And Musa bin Uqbah), gives the illusion that he narrated it with his chain. This contradicts the reality in Al-Hafiz's speech as we mentioned. The Doctor was only misled by his lack of knowledge of the art of Takhrij. In such a case, it should be said: (And Musa bin Uqbah suspendedly). Likewise, it should be said regarding the narration of Ibn Ishaq and Ibn Sa'd for this story to prevent giving an impression contrary to reality. The Doctor's denial of the existence of the addition in (At-Tabaqat) while it is in it.

[54]

book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography
text: I say: What I believe is that the noble reader will be amazed at the Doctor's amazement once we reveal the overt prejudice and flagrant ignorance of the science of Takhrij in his words. Before that, I must quote my words in the extraction of the Hadith the Doctor pointed to. I will start first by mentioning its text in the book (Al-Fiqh) then follow with my comments on it. The virtuous Sheikh Al-Ghazali, may Allah Almighty preserve him, said (p. 501): (Ibn Abbas said: When the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, became ill, he ordered Abu Bakr to pray with the people. Then he found relief, so he went out. When Abu Bakr sensed him, he wanted to step back, but the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, motioned to him. So he sat next to Abu Bakr on his left and started the recitation from the verse where Abu Bakr had ended. So Abu Bakr was following the Prophet, and the people were following Abu Bakr). So I said in its extraction verbatim: (Authentic (Sahih). Extracted by Ahmad (2055, 3330, and 3355) and Ibn Majah (1 / 373) from the path of Abu Ishaq from Al-Arqam bin Shurahbil from Ibn Abbas, and its men are trustworthy. However, Al-Busiri found a defect in it that Abu Ishaq - who is As-Sabi'i - became confused at the end of his life and was a Mudallis (concealer) and narrated it by 'an'anah (ambiguous transmission). I said: But Abdullah bin Abi As-Safar followed him [corroborated him], except that he said: from Ibn Abbas from Al-Abbas, making it from the Musnad of Al-Abbas. This is a slight difference that does not harm the authenticity of the Hadith, Allah willing. Ahmad also narrated it from this perspective (1784 and 1785). So if you, O noble reader, examine this extraction of mine and compare it with what the Doctor attributed to me, the following two facts will become clear to you: The First: The Hadith I verified is different from the Hadith about which the Doctor said: Narrated by Al-Bukhari... etc. Two matters indicate this: The First: That in it is the saying: (And he started recitation from the verse where Abu Bakr had ended). book_title: Defense of the Prophetic Hadith and Biography
text: In conclusion, I advise the Doctor not to write except in a science he has mastered and practiced for a period of time, and that his guide in that be advice to the Muslims and sincerity to the Lord of the Worlds, far from being influenced by the character of malice and envy. That is more effective for him and more beneficial in this world and the Hereafter. Imam An-Nawawi, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said in (At-Taqrib) (p. 232) briefly: [60]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
(The science of Hadith is a noble science that befits high morals and virtuous characters, and it is among the sciences of the Hereafter. Whoever is denied it is denied great good, and whoever is granted it attains abundant favor. Its possessor must correct his intention, purify his heart from worldly motives, employ beautiful morals and manners, and then empty his effort into acquiring it. Greed should not drive him to carelessness in bearing it, thereby violating any of its conditions. He should apply the Hadiths of worship and manners that he hears, for that is the Zakat (purification) of the Hadith and a cause for its preservation. He must beware, with all caution, of pride preventing him from striving fully in acquisition and taking knowledge from those below him in lineage, age, or otherwise. He should not limit himself to hearing and writing it without knowing and understanding it; rather, he should learn its authenticity, weakness, meanings, language, inflection, and the names of its narrators, verifying all of that. He should engage in Takhrij (extraction/referencing) and classification if he is qualified for it. He must beware of publishing his work except after refining, editing, and repeatedly reviewing it, and he must beware of classifying what he is not qualified for). With these great counsels, I conclude these researches now, hoping from the Mawla (Allah) Subhanahu wa Ta'ala to benefit everyone who reads them with a sound heart. And praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds. [61]

Appendix: After writing the above by a long time, I came across the third edition of this book (Fiqh as-Seerah) by Dr. Al-Buti. He claimed in its introduction (that the reader will not see any addition in it over the edition before it, nor any signs of change and alteration, except what was necessary by way of correction and revision). However, I found in it numerous errors and new ignorances that appeared in the additions found in the edition preceding it, meaning the second edition. I did not have the opportunity to view this [second] edition to see the extent to which his claim matched reality. The Doctor has done the like of this before in the introduction to the second edition of his treatise (Al-La Madhhabiyya), even though reality testified to the contrary, as proven with numbers by our companion Master Eid Abbasi in (Supplement to the Innovation of Madhhab Fanaticism) pp. (51-58). text: For At-Tabari also shared in narrating it at length in the place the Doctor pointed to, Dar al-Ma'arif edition with the mentioned number, except that the correct reference is (2/278) not (2/287). Every student of the science of terminology (Mustalah) knows that a Hasan Hadith contains some weakness because it is above the Weak Hadith and below the Sahih. Likewise, the narrator of a Hasan Hadith is lower in memory than the narrator of a Sahih Hadith. So, every Hasan Hadith has some leniency (Lin). Therefore, there is no contradiction between this and At-Tirmidhi declaring it Hasan. Fourth: I do not doubt that there is a big difference between us and Dr. Al-Buti in estimating the benefit of Hadiths of Tabarruk (seeking blessings). For me and every person of knowledge, as I believe, they are irrelevant today. This does not negate the benefit of knowing them as previously explained. While the Doctor sees that they are relevant because they indicate Tabarruk, and Tabarruk and Tawassul (intercession) are synonymous to him, as indicated by his previous statement: (The meaning of this is that there is no objection to Tawassul and Tabarruk by the traces of the Prophet... let alone Tawassul by his essence and status...) etc. More explicit is his statement in the main text of the book on page (197): (For Tawassul and Tabarruk are two words indicating one meaning, which is seeking good and blessing through the path of Tawassul by it. Both Tawassul by his status (peace and blessings be upon him) with Allah and Tawassul by his traces, secretions, or clothes are individuals and particulars falling under a comprehensive type which is absolute Tawassul, whose ruling is established by Sahih Hadiths. All its particular forms fall under the generality of the text by means of what is called (refining the basis/Tanqih al-Manat) according to the scholars of Usul). He declared in another place (p. 355) that the basis (Manat) is solely him (peace and blessings be upon him) being the best of creatures with Allah absolutely. I say: In this speech there is much confusion and mixing, and claiming what has no origin and what is irrational. Just as there is not even a single Hadith confirming the absolute Tawassul that the Doctor claimed (The imitator who says what no Mujtahid in the world has said). Why didn't he mention some of those Hadiths that prove absolute Tawassul and explain the face of their indication of what he claimed, instead of turning away from this speech and the clamor without grinding? [77]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
Then how can he make Tawassul synonymous with Tabarruk, when Tawassul according to him does not require the presence of the one by whom Tawassul is sought, as is explicit in his speech, and [distinguish it from] Tabarruk which requires the presence of the object by which blessing is sought, as is apparent in the Hadiths mentioned by Professor Al-Buti and before him Al-Kattani and others? Otherwise, how is it possible to seek blessings by them? Also, his speech is explicit in the permissibility of Tawassul by saying in his supplication: (O Allah, I seek intercession to You by the secretions of Your Prophet, his sweat, and...) and other things that every sane Muslim jealous for the station of Divinity would be ashamed to write, let alone utter. Oh the shame if the Doctor stood on the pulpit on Friday praying with this supplication, confirming what he adopted of the philosophy of Tawassul by waste products. By Allah, we have increased in certainty regarding the illegitimacy of Tawassul by the Essence (Dhat) when we saw Dr. Al-Buti implying from it the legitimacy of Tawassul by a part of the parts of the Essence, even if it is from the kind that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) himself used to clean and purify himself from, as is established in the (Two Sahihs) and other books of the purified Sunnah. Fifth: It has become clear from what passed that what Dr. Al-Buti thought was the reason is a sinful suspicion. Because, first, I did not cancel the benefit of Hadiths of seeking blessings by his traces (peace and blessings be upon him) as previously explained. And second, because it is based on his false equalization between Tabarruk and Tawassul on one hand, and on the legitimacy of Tawassul by the Essence on the other hand, and both are incorrect as we presented, even if briefly. As for his winking at me regarding oddity (Shudhudh) in his saying: (that they oppose his school regarding Tawassul), it arises from his lack of observing manners with the Imams who oppose his opinion - I do not say his school (Madhhab) - for he has no school despite his 'non-Madhhabism'. Otherwise, where is he regarding the statement of Imam Abu Hanifa: (I detest that one asks Allah except by Allah). The Imam did not permit asking by the Essence, let alone by waste products as is the opinion of the 'Imitator Mujtahid Gatherer of Contradictions'. What the Imam went to is the school of his two companions as well, let alone Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah and Ibn al-Qayyim and others among the verifiers. It is the school supported by Prophetic Hadiths and Salafi traditions as you see detailed in my special treatise on Tawassul, along with the refutation of the doubts of the opposers and critiquing them via narration [78]

and understanding. Included in that is the detailed refutation of Al-Buti in his mixing between Tawassul and Tabarruk and his permitting Tawassul by waste products. This article will not reach the hands of the noble readers before the treatise has been circulated and benefited from, Allah willing, by everyone who has a heart or lends an ear while he is a witness. Apologies to the readers for being compelled to prolong the refutation of Al-Buti in this paragraph, which dragged us into departing from what we are concerned with regarding refuting him from the purely Hadith perspective, to which I directed myself in these articles, without discussing his Fiqh opinions in which he opposed the Sharia evidences. Perhaps I will find time later to write on that by the permission of Allah the Exalted. Let us return now to what we are concerned with, so I say:

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
4 - He said (p. 213): (Ibn Ishaq mentioned this book [document] without a chain. And Ibn Khaythamah mentioned it and connected it: Ahmad ibn Janab Abu Al-Walid told us, Isa ibn Yunus told us, Kathir ibn Abdullah ibn Amr Al-Muzani told us, from his father, from his grandfather that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) wrote a writing between the Muhajireen and the Ansar... so he mentioned similar to what Ibn Ishaq mentioned. See 'Uyun al-Athar by Ibn Sayyid An-Nas) (1/198). I say regarding it there are criticisms: First: This chain has no value because Kathir ibn Abdullah ibn Amr Al-Muzani is very weak. Adh-Dhahabi said in (Ad-Du'afa wal-Matrukin): (Ash-Shafi'i said about him: One of the pillars of lying. Ibn Hibban said: He has a fabricated copy from his father from his grandfather. Others said: Weak). Second: If the Doctor does not know this severe weakness due to his ignorance of the biographies of Hadith narrators, why did he mention its chain? His students and the majority of his book's readers are naturally not better than him in that. And if he knew it, why did he conceal it and not explain it? Do we not have the right, with all this, to narrate the saying of the one who said: [79]

If you do not know, that is a calamity, and if you know, the calamity is greater. Third: If he knew that, what is the benefit of it other than inflating the size of the book? Does the Doctor not know that a weak Hadith is not strengthened by what is severely weak according to the scholars of Hadith, nor is it used as a witnessing evidence (Istishhad), especially if the witnessed report has no chain at all, as is the case of this book [document] according to Ibn Ishaq? Fourth: How does all this agree with his saying that he relied on authentic news of the Seerah? Where is the authenticity in what has no chain and its witness is very weak? Fifth: His saying: (Ibn Khaythamah) is an error indicating the extent of the Doctor's knowledge of biographies. The correct name is (Ibn Abi Khaythamah) as in (Al-'Uyun) and others.

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
5 - Then he said immediately following that (p. 214): (And Imam Ahmad mentioned it in his Musnad, narrating it from Surayj who said: Abbad told us, from Hajjaj, from Amr ibn Shu'ayb, from his father, from his grandfather that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) wrote a writing between the Muhajireen and the Ansar... etc. See Musnad Ahmad 21/10 Sharh al-Banna). I say: There are criticisms in it as well: First: Its chain is weak and cannot be used as proof because this Hajjaj is Ibn Artah, and Al-Hafiz said about him in (At-Taqrib): (Truthful, makes many mistakes and practices Tadlis [concealment]). It seems that Sheikh Abdur-Rahman Al-Banna imagined he was another one of the trustworthy narrators, so he said: (And its chain is Sahih). Second, Third, and Fourth are like what preceded in the Hadith before it. Fifth: His saying: (...etc). I say: In it is an illusion contrary to reality that should not issue from one who cares that his speech or what he writes matches reality. For anyone who stands upon his saying this after the Hadith before it which contains (so he mentioned similar to what Ibn Ishaq mentioned), then he conjoined to it saying: (And Imam Ahmad mentioned it in his Musnad...), understands from it nothing other than that what Ahmad mentioned is like, or at least similar to, what Ibn Ishaq mentioned in meaning and completeness. This is contrary to Ahmad's narration, for it is very brief compared to Ibn Ishaq's context. Its wording is: [80]

(He wrote a writing between the Muhajireen and the Ansar that they should pay their blood monies, and they should ransom their captives with kindness and reconciliation among the Muslims). Where is this brief context compared to Ibn Ishaq's context which reaches about two pages of the size of this magazine's page? Sufficient indication for you is that Al-Buti mentioned (13) paragraphs from it, which are still few from many. If this indicates anything, it indicates that in his writings he does not seek correctness and precise expression matching reality. This is assuming he did not intend that to block the path of one who might criticize him for relying on Ibn Ishaq's narration which has no chain. For its chain consists of the two mentioned Hadiths as witnesses for it, and they contain what you learned of severe weakness in the first, and severe brevity with weakness in the other.

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: 6 - He said (p. 226) after mentioning the Hadith of Al-Hubab ibn Al-Mundhir regarding his advice to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) to camp in a place other than the one he (peace and blessings be upon him) had camped in: (Ibn Hisham narrated this Hadith of Al-Hubab ibn Al-Mundhir in his Seerah from Ibn Ishaq from men of Banu Salamah. So in what Ibn Hisham narrated, it is a narration from unknown people. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar mentioned this Hadith in (Al-Isabah) and narrated it from Ibn Ishaq from Yazid ibn Ruman from Urwah ibn Az-Zubayr and more than one in the story of Badr, and this is a Sahih chain. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar is trustworthy in what he transfers and narrates. (Refer to Al-Isabah 1/302). I say: We have observations on it: First: His defecting Ibn Hisham's narration because it is from unknown people is not a damaging defect because they are a group whose anonymity is overlooked by the scholars of this field, especially since it is probable they are from the Sahabah (Companions). Because Ibn Ishaq narrated it like this: 'I was told by men from Banu Salamah'. If Ibn Ishaq had explicitly stated narration [Haddathana] from the men, the mentioned probability would be negated because Ibn Ishaq is from the followers of the Tabi'in, and we would be certain that the Hadith is Mursal. [81]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
But his saying: (I was told / Huddithtu) is evidence that there is an intermediary between him and the men, and it is possible that he is from the Tabi'in, so the mentioned probability remains standing. Rather, the damaging defect in this narration is the anonymity of the intermediary along with the probability of Irsaal (disconnection). Second: His saying regarding Urwah's narration: (And this is a Sahih chain) is not correct in an absolute sense due to two matters: The first: That Ibn Ishaq has some talk regarding his memory, and the settled opinion of investigating scholars is that his Hadith is in the rank of Hasan with two conditions: That he explicitly states narration [Tahdith to avoid Tadlis] and that he does not oppose one who is more trustworthy than him. The other matter: That Urwah is a Tabi'i who did not witness the event. So the correct statement is to say: Its chain is Mursal Hasan. In that case, it is a weak chain because Mursal is one of the categories of Weak according to the rules of Hadith scholars as established in its place. I find no face for the Doctor's mentioned saying except that he thinks Urwah ibn Az-Zubayr is a Companion like his brother Abdullah. If it is so, it is a strange thought that reveals the extent of the Doctor's knowledge of the men of the Salaf. Another Hadith of this type passed from him in the third chapter, Hadith six, pp. (19-20). Third: His saying about Al-Hafiz: (So he narrated it from Ibn Ishaq from Yazid) is an error, and like it is his saying afterwards: (transfers and narrates). Because narration (Riwayah) according to Muhaddithin does not mean mere mentioning of the narrated item and transferring it, but rather mentioning it with the narrator's chain from him to its end. The detail of that passed in the refutation of the Doctor's saying: (Ibn Kathir narrated) (p. 15), so refer to it. If he said: (narrates and transfers) it would have been closer to correctness on the consideration of his saying: (and transfers) being an explanation of his saying: (narrates). As for the reverse, it is incorrect due to what I mentioned. Fourth: His saying about Al-Hafiz also: (from Ibn Ishaq from Yazid) is an error of his against Al-Hafiz, because he only said: (Ibn Ishaq said in 'As-Seerah': Yazid told me [Haddathani] [82]

ibn Ruman...). There is a big difference between the two sayings for one who knows that Ibn Ishaq is a Mudallis (concealer), and that if he says (from / 'an), it is not a proof, but if he says: (told me / Haddathani), it is a proof. If the Doctor had knowledge of this, he would not have attributed to Al-Hafiz what he did not say, Allah the Exalted willing. Fifth: There is no doubt that Al-Hafiz is trustworthy, rather above trustworthy, but that does not mean he is infallible from error as the Shia say of their Imams. This narration which he mentioned from Urwah, I have not seen anyone mention it, like Ibn Sayyid An-Nas and Ibn Kathir and others. In addition to that, it is not in (Seerah Ibn Hisham) (2/272). Yes, it appeared in it before that (1/263): (Ibn Ishaq said: And Yazid ibn Ruman told me from Urwah ibn Az-Zubayr who said...). I say: So he mentioned a part of the Battle of Badr, then followed it with many other parts, beginning each part of them with his saying: (Ibn Ishaq said). Then Ibn Hisham said: Ibn Ishaq said: So I was told by men... etc. So he mentioned the story of Al-Hubab. I say: It is probable that when Al-Hafiz transferred it, his eye fell on the first chain from Urwah and his gaze did not fall on his second chain: 'from men of Banu Salamah', so it became from the narration of Urwah. But one could say: This is a strong probability were it not that Al-Hafiz joined to Urwah his saying: (and more than one). This is not in the Seerah at all, so where did he get it from? I say: This is something for which I have no answer now. It bears a remote probability that Al-Hafiz transferred Urwah's narration and 'more than one' directly from (Seerah Ibn Ishaq), so it would contain what is not in (Seerah Ibn Hisham) from him. This is very unlikely. And Allah knows best.

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
7 - He said (p. 246): (To explain this rule, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) says in what Al-Bukhari narrated from Omar (may Allah be pleased with him): (We only take you now by what appears to us from your deeds...). And he says in what the Two Sheikhs narrated: (You dispute before me...) the Hadith). I say: This is an obscene sin that cannot be tolerated. For the Hadith in Al-Bukhari and others is not from the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him); rather, it is from the saying of Omar (may Allah be pleased with him) suspended (Mawquf) upon him. It is in [83]

Al-Bukhari in the beginning of the Book of (Witnesses) via Abdullah ibn Utbah who said: I heard Omar ibn Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) say: (Indeed, people used to be taken by revelation during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), but the revelation has ceased. And we only take you now by what appears to us from your deeds). Imam Ahmad also extracted it via another path from Omar as Mawquf similar to it. The most likely reason for the issuance of this sin from Dr. Al-Buti is firstly lack of checking what came in the Sunnah as is required, and secondly speed of copying without awareness and attention, because he transfers what he has not digested. Otherwise, if he were aware, this would not have happened from him by Allah's permission. Perhaps when he saw in the Hadith the saying: (Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him), he imagined that what followed it was his saying (peace and blessings be upon him). From the Doctor's saying after it: (And he says in what the Two Sheikhs narrated...), the reader knows that his saying in the first Hadith: (The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, says) is not an addition from the printer that the Doctor overlooked when correcting proofs, evidenced by his conjoining the second Hadith to the first Hadith which the Doctor explicitly stated and wrote with his pen was raised (Marfu') to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him). So he conjoined the second to it, and this one is known to be raised to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) unlike the first. Were it not for that explicit statement, the mentioned conjunction would not be correct as is apparent. Among the Doctor's oddities and strange things is that in the first edition, he had placed another Hadith in place of this Hadith of Omar, the wording of which was: (To explain this rule, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, says: We were ordered to judge by the apparent, and Allah handles the secrets). When our companion Master Eid Abbasi criticized him and explained to him that this Hadith has no origin, he deleted it and the Doctor printed in its place this Hadith of Omar which is Mawquf in Al-Bukhari, but he attributed it to him as Marfu' (raised to Prophet). If this indicates anything, it is that the Doctor was not successful in this amendment by which he increased in distance from correctness. Perhaps the Doctor has taken a lesson not to be arrogant again about admitting his error and thanking the one who alerted him to it, thereby giving a practical lesson to students and readers reminding them of the morals of pious scholars.

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
8 - He said (p. 288): (And it is also proven in the Two Sahihs that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) [84]

asked Jabir in the Ghazwah (expedition) of Dhat Ar-Riqa: Did you marry? He said: Yes). I say: The mention of the Ghazwah of Dhat Ar-Riqa is not in the (Two Sahihs) nor in either of them. The Doctor attributing that to them is one of his errors that are endless. Rather, that is in (Seerah Ibn Hisham) from Ibn Ishaq from Jabir, and its chain is Hasan. Ahmad also narrated it (375-376). Al-Bukhari commented a part of its beginning in (Al-Maghazi). Rather, he has in (Ash-Shurut) also as Mu'allaq (suspended) via another path from Jabir what implies that this was in the Ghazwah of Tabuk, but Al-Hafiz preferred Ibn Ishaq's narration over it. Let whoever wishes refer to it.

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
9 - He said (pp. 366-367) having mentioned the Hadith of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) kissing Ja'far ibn Abi Talib between his eyes and embracing him upon his arrival from Abyssinia: (And the Hadith was narrated by Abu Dawud with a Sahih chain). I say: This is an error like his error in his previous saying regarding Urwah's Mursal report: (Sahih chain) as previously explained (p. 81, para 6). For Abu Dawud extracted it at the end of his book via Ali ibn Mushir from Ajlah from Ash-Sha'bi that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) met Ja'far ibn Abi Talib, embraced him, and kissed what was between his eyes. I say: So Ash-Sha'bi is a known Tabi'i who did not witness the incident naturally, so the chain is interrupted (Munqati') and Mursal. And Al-Ajlah, who is Ibn Abdullah ibn Hujayyah Al-Kindi, is disputed; a group authenticated him and others weakened him, including Abu Dawud himself. Al-'Uqayli said: He narrated from Ash-Sha'bi disturbed (Mudtarib) Hadiths that are not corroborated. Adh-Dhahabi listed him in (Ad-Du'afa) number (229) of (Al-Mughni) and said: (Shi'i, there is no harm in his Hadith, some softened him. Al-Juzjani said: Al-Ajlah is a fabricator). Al-Hafiz said in (At-Taqrib): (Truthful, Shi'i). I say: The likes of him, his Hadith is not authenticated (Sahih) except by one who has no knowledge of the science of Hadith terminology and biographies of men. Rather, he only considers it Hasan if he is not among the strict ones. So the correct statement is [85]

to say: (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a Hasan Mursal chain). And the more correct is to say: Narrated by Abu Dawud with a weak chain, because most readers do not know that the Mursal - according to Muhaddithin - is from the category of Weak Hadith like the Munqati', Mudallis, Mu'dal and others. This is all regarding Abu Dawud's narration. Otherwise, Al-Hakim narrated it (3/211) via Al-Hasan ibn Al-Husayn Al-'Urani, Ajlah ibn Abdullah told us, from Ash-Sha'bi from Jabir who said: So he mentioned the Hadith like this connected (Musnad) from Jabir. But this Al-'Urani was listed by Adh-Dhahabi in (Ad-Du'afa) and said (1389): (He is not truthful). I say: So the likes of him are not used as proof at all, so how can he be when he opposed the likes of Ali ibn Mushir, the Trustworthy (Thiqah) used as proof in the (Two Sahihs)? Rather, even if trustworthy narrators narrated it from Al-Ajlah connected from Jabir, it would not be Sahih because he opposed two trustworthy narrators, Ismail ibn Abi Khalid and Zakariyya ibn Abi Za'idah, who narrated it from Ash-Sha'bi as Mursal. Al-Hakim extracted it. So how is it when Al-Ajlah agreed with them in the authentic narration from him? That is why Adh-Dhahabi said in (Talkhis al-Mustadrak): (I say: And the Mursal is the correct one).

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: 10 - Then he said: (And At-Tirmidhi narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: Zaid ibn Harithah arrived in Medina while the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was in my house. He came to him and knocked on the door, so the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) stood up to him dragging his garment, embraced him, and kissed him). I say: Its chain is weak, sequenced with three weak narrators in a row as I explained in my critique of Al-Kattani (p. 16 - Hadith Eighth). That is why Adh-Dhahabi said: (Munkar Hadith). So how does the Doctor's inclusion of this Hadith in his book meet with his saying that he relied in it on the authentic Sunnah? And if he has a special opinion opposing Imam Adh-Dhahabi's judgment and what I explained there, why didn't he refute us as he did in the three Hadiths regarding which the refutation of him passed? Or is he convinced within himself of the weakness of its chain explained there, for he is certainly aware of it, and that is why he did not turn to criticize it? In that case, the burden of citing it is greater. May Allah reform him and guide him. [86]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: 11 - He mentioned (p. 441) the Hadith of Omar ibn Al-Khattab regarding his racing with Abu Bakr As-Siddiq and Abu Bakr donating all his wealth, and his saying (may Allah be pleased with him): (I have left Allah and His Messenger for them). And he said in its Takhrij in the footnote: (Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, Al-Hakim, and Abu Dawud. In its chain is Hisham ibn Sa'd from Zaid ibn Aslam. Imam Ahmad and An-Nasa'i (Original says Al-Kisa'i) weakened him, and Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar considered him of the fifth rank, saying about him: Truthful, has delusions. However, Adh-Dhahabi quoted from Abu Dawud that he is the most established of people when he narrates from Zaid ibn Aslam as in this Hadith, and quoted from Al-Hakim that Muslim extracted from him in the supporting evidences (Shawahid)). The Doctor said following the Hadith in the main text of the book: (And if this Hadith is authentic...). And he referred to it (p. 451) and said: (Despite the probabilities of weakness in it which I explained in the Takhrij of the Hadith). I say: This is a new type from the Doctor in Takhrij. While we previously saw him limiting himself in Takhrij of Hadiths to merely mentioning who extracted it without judging it with what it deserves of authenticity or weakness - and often it is weak so he remains silent about it, giving the illusion of its authenticity as passed repeatedly - suddenly we see him here reversing that and trying to weaken the established Hadith, clinging to the talk regarding the mentioned Hisham ibn Sa'd. Even though his Hadith, according to the people of knowledge of Jarh and Ta'dil and biographies of men, does not fall below the rank of Hasan. Because they know that the mere fact of a narrator being spoken about does not make his Hadith in the rank of Weak, for there is a middle rank between it and the rank of Sahih, which is Hasan. Hisham is of this type, especially in his narration from Ibn Aslam due to his frequent narration from him and his companionship with him. No wonder At-Tirmidhi, Al-Hakim, and Adh-Dhahabi authenticated his Hadith; rather, Imam Al-Bukhari used him as proof and cited him in suspended form (Mu'allaq) in his (Sahih) with the formula of certainty (Jazm) (Number 228 - Mukhtasar Sahih Al-Bukhari). Therefore, I extracted it in (Sahih Abi Dawud) [87]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
Despite all this, we find Dr. Al-Buti ignoring, if not ignorant of, the authentication of it by these Imams, and trying to attribute weakness to it as if he views himself as having reached the highest rank in the science of Hadith and its criticism, taking complete independence in it. If another had done that - especially if he were from the Salafis - he would have stood up and sat down, thundered and foamed, and pretended Islamic zeal and religious jealousy for the station of the Imams in the hearts of the Ummah, and attributed it to slandering them and not respecting them, exactly as he says about the Salafis and accuses them of many charges because they do not adhere to the Madhhab of a specific Imam but take the saying of any Imam among them in what agrees with the Book and Sunnah according to them. So let the noble reader reflect on the wisdom of the Wise, the Knowing, how He makes the circle turn upon the aggressor. This is first. As for second: Let the intelligent person look at his saying: (And despite the probabilities of weakness in it which I explained). I say: Where are these alleged probabilities? For the Doctor only explained one probability, which is nevertheless rejected by the authentication of those Imams for it. Third: Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath) (3/229) regarding the Hadith, and Al-Bukhari had commented a part of it as previously mentioned: (This is famous in the Seerahs... it appeared in a Marfu' Hadith extracted by Abu Dawud, and At-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim authenticated it...). He mentioned it then said: (Hisham ibn Sa'd was unique with it from Zaid, and Hisham is truthful, having some speech regarding his memory). I say: The Doctor mentioned many Hadiths of the Seerah and its stories which are less famous than this Hadith, and among them are those known to have no chain at all, mentioning them as if they were authentic. So how did the fame of this Hadith, along with the Imams' authentication of it, not intercede for him to include it without any criticism from himself? He knows that he has no methodology or school he adheres to in authenticating Hadiths [88]

and classifying them. Rather, his matter in that is as the common people say (cut and paste). Fourth: Al-Buti prioritized At-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim over Abu Dawud in mentioning, and what is known among scholars is the opposite. No one among them prioritizes At-Tirmidhi, let alone Al-Hakim, over Abu Dawud. Rather, they say: Narrated by Abu Dawud, At-Tirmidhi, and Al-Hakim. Just as they say: Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Abu Dawud. They do not reverse that at all. That is out of manners from them by way of putting people in their places. Has Al-Buti not memorized this manner from them until today, having become a Doctor, or has knowledge become clear to him that the ancients did not encompass, so he permitted himself to oppose them in their manners and method? Let not the reader think that this is a slip of the pen from the Doctor, for he said on page 450: (We mentioned the Hadith which At-Tirmidhi and Abu Dawud narrated regarding Abu Bakr presenting all his money...). And he said on the page after it: (Indeed, the Hadith of At-Tirmidhi, Al-Hakim, and Abu Dawud). If this indicates anything, it is that the Doctor does not refer to books of Hadith except very rarely. Otherwise, their manner in the mentioned arrangement would not be hidden from him, and this is clear and not hidden, and praise be to Allah. I almost said due to the multitude of these errors: These Takhrijs and comments are not by the pen of the Doctor himself; rather, they are by the pen of one of his students, and not the brilliant ones among them.

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: 12 - He said (p. 442): (And Imam Ahmad narrated in his Musnad from Abu Hurairah who said: When it was the Ghazwah of Tabuk, the people were struck by famine...). I say: So he mentioned the Hadith at length and commented on it saying: (Narrated by Ahmad in his Musnad, and Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir mentioned it in his History then said: Muslim narrated it from Abu Kurayb from Abu Mu'awiyah from Al-A'mash). I say: This comment, despite its brevity, contains disturbing repetition not hidden from the reader. Worse than it is his quoting Ibn Kathir's speech cut off, for the completion of Ibn Kathir's speech is (...from Al-A'mash bi-hi [with it/via the same chain]). The word (bi-hi) might have been dropped by the printer and the Doctor did not notice it when correcting proofs. But even so, what is the benefit of this quote then, especially when it is a matter the Doctor did not follow [89]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: in all his comments without introduction and explanation for it? And what is the meaning of his saying: (from Abu Kurayb from Abu Mu'awiyah from Al-A'mash)? Is the end of this chain, who is Al-A'mash named Sulayman ibn Mihran, one of the young Tabi'in, making the Hadith Mursal based on this? Is this the intended meaning of the mentioned chain? No. So what is it then? Even if we assume that the word (bi-hi) fell from the printer and not from the Doctor himself. Indeed, Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir mentioned the Hadith and presented its chain beforehand, saying: (Imam Ahmad narrated it from Mu'awiyah from Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from Abu Hurairah or from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri - Al-A'mash doubted - who said...). I say: So he mentioned the Hadith then said at its end: (And Muslim narrated it from Abu Kurayb from Abu Mu'awiyah from Al-A'mash bi-hi). With this, one who has knowledge of Hadith and its chains can understand that this saying of Ibn Kathir means that Muslim narrated it via Abu Kurayb who followed Abu Mu'awiyah, the Sheikh of Imam Ahmad, in his narration of the Hadith from Abu Mu'awiyah from Al-A'mash bi-hi, meaning with the mentioned chain of Al-A'mash found in Ahmad. Meaning that both Abu Mu'awiyah and Abu Kurayb narrated the Hadith from Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from Abu Hurairah or from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, like this with doubt between Abu Hurairah and Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri. If you know this, O noble reader, say by your Lord, what is the benefit gained by the reader of Al-Buti's book if he [Al-Buti] undertook explaining this meaning intended by Ibn Kathir by his previous statement? So how is it when it is unexplained by him? How rich he would have been without mentioning it if he limited himself in the Takhrij to his saying: (Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim) as is his habit regarding this book and others. After this, a new error of Professor Al-Buti has become clear to the readers in his mentioned Takhrij, which is that he attributed the Hadith to the narration of Ahmad and Muslim from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, while in both of them it is from Abu Hurairah or from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri with doubt as I explained. Ibn Kathir also attributed it to them [90]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
13 - He mentioned (p. 502) the agreed-upon Hadith: (May Allah's curse be upon the Jews and the Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques). He said following it: 'It is as if he warns the Muslims against doing with him what they did.' I say: This statement from the Doctor informs the scholar of Hadith of one of two things: Either the Doctor is so ignorant that he has no knowledge of Hadith, or he intentionally distorts the narration of the Hadith. That is because the mentioned warning, which the Doctor made out to be his own deduction, is actually part of the complete text of the agreed-upon Hadith. It is from the Hadith of Aisha and Abdullah ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both), for they said immediately following the Hadith: (He was warning against what they did). This is how Al-Bukhari extracted it (1/422, 6/386, 10/227 - Fath al-Bari), and Muslim (2/67), Ad-Darimi (1/326), and Ahmad (1/218). The latter explicitly stated that this is from the speech of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her). This is a benefit that Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar missed pointing out, as he said in Al-Fath (1/423): (His saying: 'He was warning against what they did' is another new sentence from the speech of the narrator, as if he was asked about the wisdom of mentioning that at that time, so he answered with that). Therefore, the saying: (He was warning against what they did) is from the speech of the narrator of the Hadith, as Al-Hafiz explicitly stated, and she is Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) as in Ahmad's narration. So how did the Doctor make it his own speech? This action of his reminds me of a type of impugning Hadith narrators known as 'stealing Hadith'; a narrator would hear of a Hadith narrated by some, so he would steal it from him and attach one of his own chains to it, then raise it to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him). As for the Doctor, he attributed the Hadith [commentary] to himself. However, I cannot assert that he intended that, due to my certainty that his memorization of Prophetic Hadiths is very little. So it is strongly probable that he does not know that the sentence: (He was warning against what they did) is in the Hadith, so he explained it from his own mind. Furthermore, the Doctor's saying: (It is as if he, peace and blessings be upon him, warns...) contains clear skepticism that he (peace and blessings be upon him) intended the warning. [91]

And this contradicts, with explicit contradiction, the certainty of Sayyidah Aisha regarding that in her saying: (He was warning against what they did). How could it not be so, when the witness sees what the absent does not see? As he (peace and blessings be upon him) said (1). So contemplate what ignorance of Hadith does in terms of distorting and altering the explicit authentic text.

14 - He said (p. 521) while listing the faces indicating the legitimacy of visiting his grave (peace and blessings be upon him): (The second face: What is established of the consensus of the Companions, the Tabi'in, and those after them regarding visiting his grave (peace and blessings be upon him) and greeting him every time they passed by the Noble Rawdah. This was narrated by the prominent Imams and the majority of scholars, including Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him). I say: This is a lie against the prominent Imams, especially Ibn Taymiyyah, the Sheikh of Islam. For none of them narrated from the mentioned people that they visited the Noble Grave every time they passed by the Rawdah, let alone transmitting consensus on it. Rather, Imam Malik textually stated that such an action is disliked (Makruh). The sayings of the scholars witnessing to what I say are many; I will content myself with two sayings from them: One from Ibn Taymiyyah, the one slandered against, and the other from Imam An-Nawawi, considering him one of the Shafi'i Imams whom Dr. Al-Buti imitates.

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: 1 - As for Ibn Taymiyyah, his statements are very many in this regard. Here are two texts from them: First: His saying: (The Companions did not used to enter near the grave, nor stand by it from the outside, even though they entered his mosque night and day. They used to arrive from journeys to meet the Rightly Guided Caliphs and others, so they would pray in his mosque and send peace upon him in the prayer and upon entering the mosque and exiting it. They would not come to the grave because that was, according to them, something he did not command them to do nor institute as a Sunnah for them. He only commanded and instituted for them the prayer and sending peace upon him in the prayer and when entering mosques and so on. However, Ibn Umar used to come to him and greet him and his two companions upon his arrival from travel. Others besides Ibn Umar might have done it too. For this reason, those scholars who viewed this as permissible did so following the example of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them. Ibn Umar used to greet [him]
foot_note:
1. (1) I say: It is extracted in my work (Al-Ahadith As-Sahihah) number (1904). 
[92].

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
then leave and would not stand. He would say: 'Peace be upon you, O Messenger of Allah. Peace be upon you, O Abu Bakr. Peace be upon you, O my father,' then he would leave. The majority of the Companions did not do as Ibn Umar did; rather, the Caliphs and others would travel for Hajj and other things and return without doing that, because this was not, in their view, a Sunnah he instituted for them. Likewise, his wives during the era of the Caliphs and after them would travel for Hajj then each one would return to her house as he instructed them. The delegations of Yemen, about whom Allah the Exalted said: {Allah will bring forth a people He will love and who will love Him}, used to come in crowds from Yemen for Jihad in the path of Allah during the era of Abu Bakr and Umar. They would pray behind Abu Bakr and Umar in his mosque, and not one of them would enter inside the chamber nor stand in the mosque outside of it, neither for supplication, nor for prayer, nor for greeting, nor for anything else. They were knowledgeable of his Sunnah as the Companions and Tabi'in taught them). This is in his book (Al-Jawab Al-Bahir fi Zuwwar Al-Maqabir) (p. 60 - Salafi Edition). Second: His saying in his refutation of Al-Akhna'i (p. 45): (As for what is thought to be a visit to his grave (peace and blessings be upon him), such as standing outside the chamber for greeting and supplication, this is not recommended for the people of Medina. Rather, they are forbidden from it, because the first predecessors from the Muhajireen and Ansar and those who followed them in good - the Rightly Guided Caliphs and others - used to enter his mosque for the five prayers and other things. The grave was at the wall of the mosque, and they did not go to it nor stand by it. Malik and other scholars mentioned this; they stated that it is not recommended, rather it is disliked (Makruh) for residents of Medina to stand at the grave for greeting or otherwise, because the righteous predecessors did not do that when they entered the mosque for the five prayers and others during the era of the Rightly Guided Caliphs, Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, and Ali, may Allah be pleased with them. For they used to lead people in prayer in the mosque, and people would come from the regions to pray with them. It is known that if it were recommended for them to stand adjacent to the grave and greet or supplicate or do other than that, they would have done so. And if they had done it, it would have been frequent, apparent, and famous. However, Malik and others specified the legislation of that for when traveling, based on what was transmitted from Ibn Umar. Qadi Iyad said: [93]

Malik said: There is no harm for one who arrived from a journey or set out for a journey to stand at the grave of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and send prayers upon him and supplicate for him and for Abu Bakr and Umar. It was said to him: 'What about people from the people of Medina who are not arriving from a journey nor intending one, doing that once or more in a day, and perhaps they stand on Friday and on days once or twice or more than that at the grave, sending greetings and supplicating for an hour?' He said: 'This has not reached me from the people of Fiqh in our land, and leaving it is ample. The latter part of this Ummah will not be rectified except by what rectified its first part. It has not reached me regarding the first of this Ummah and its early generation that they used to do that, and it is disliked except for one who came from a journey or intended one').

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
2 - An-Nawawi said in his book (Manasik al-Hajj) (69/2 - Manuscript): (Malik, may Allah have mercy on him, disliked for the people of Medina to stand at the grave every time one of them entered or exited. He said: That is only for strangers. He said: And there is no harm for one who arrived from a journey or set out for a journey to stand at the grave of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and send prayers upon him and supplicate for him and for Abu Bakr and Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both. Al-Baji said: Malik distinguished between the people of Medina and strangers because strangers intended that [visit], while the people of Medina are residents there, and he (peace and blessings be upon him) said: O Allah, do not make my grave an idol to be worshipped). I say: These statements from Imam An-Nawawi and Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah are explicit in invalidating the consensus that Al-Buti reported. Rather, they speak to the illegitimacy of what he mentioned, and that he lied against the scholars in general and Ibn Taymiyyah in particular regarding what he attributed to them of narration. So what does the fair, unbiased person say about such a human who does not care what comes out of his mouth? To Allah is the complaint. Then the Doctor said: (The third face: What is established of the visit of many Companions to his grave (peace and blessings be upon him), among them Bilal, may Allah be pleased with him. Ibn Asakir narrated it with a Jayyid [good] chain). I say regarding it are matters: First: He was vague to the readers regarding the text of Ibn Asakir's narration and sufficed with pointing to it [94]

because if he quoted it in full, its falsehood would become clear to the people, even if they did not know the weakness of its chain. So it was necessary for me to quote the narration so that the noble readers may be certain with us that the Doctor does not proceed in what he writes according to a verified scientific method; rather, it is whim and motive, and according to the alleged rule (the end justifies the means). Al-Hafiz Ibn Asakir narrated in (Tarikh Dimashq) in the biography of Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn Bilal ibn Abi Darda' Al-Ansari (Vol 2 Part 4 25/1) with his chain from him, saying: My father Muhammad ibn Sulayman told me, from his father Sulayman ibn Bilal, from Umm Darda', from Abu Darda' who said: (So he mentioned the story of Bilal's arrival in Sham during the era of Umar, then said): (Then Bilal saw the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) in his sleep saying to him: 'What is this estrangement, O Bilal? Is it not time for you to visit me, O Bilal?' So he woke up sad, fearful, and afraid. He rode his mount and headed for Medina. He came to the grave of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and began to cry at it and rub his face on it. Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn came, and he began hugging and kissing them. They said to him: 'O Bilal, we desire to hear your Adhan which you used to call for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) at dawn.' So he did. He climbed the roof of the mosque and stood in the place where he used to stand. When he said: (Allah is Greatest), Medina shook. When he said: (I bear witness that there is no god but Allah), its shaking increased. When he said: (I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah), peace and blessings be upon him, the young women came out of their private quarters saying: 'Has the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) been sent [resurrected]?' No day was seen with more weeping men and women after the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) than that day). I say: This narration is false and fabricated. The signs of fabrication upon it are apparent from several aspects, the most important of which are:

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
1 - His saying: (He came to the grave of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and began to cry at it). This portrays to us that his grave (peace and blessings be upon him) was visible like other graves in graveyards that anyone can come to. This is intuitively false according to anyone who knows the history of the burial of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) in the chamber of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) [95]

and her house, which no one is allowed to enter except with her permission. Likewise was the matter during the era of Umar (may Allah be pleased with him). It is established that when he was stabbed (may Allah be pleased with him), he ordered his son Abdullah to go to Aisha and say to her: 'Umar says to you: If it does not harm you or restrict you, I would love to be buried with my two companions.' She said: 'That does not harm me nor restrict me.' He said: 'Then bury me with them.' Extracted by Al-Hakim (3/93). Then he extracted (4/7) with his Sahih chain from her that she said: (I used to enter the house in which he was buried with them, and by Allah, I never entered except with my clothes wrapped tight around me out of shyness from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him). The Noble Grave remained in Aisha's house until after her death, rather until the end of the century of the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them). Then they entered the house [into the mosque complex] and joined it to the mosque to expand it, so it became inside the mosque in the manner seen today. One who has no knowledge of the reality of the matter might think that when the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) died, the Companions buried him in the mosque - far be it from them to do that. Rather, they buried him in the house, then what we mentioned happened afterwards, contrary to what many ignorant people think, including the fabricator of this story who gave an image of the grave contradicting the reality of that day and the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them), as explained by Sheikh al-Islam and other verifiers. I mentioned a part of it in my book (Tahdhir As-Sajid min Ittikhadh Al-Qubur Masajid - Warning the Prostrator against taking Graves as Mosques), so whoever wishes may refer to it.

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
2 - His saying: (and rub his face on it). I say: This is another proof of the fabrication of this story and the ignorance of its fabricator. For he depicts Bilal (may Allah be pleased with him) as one of those ignorant people who do not stop at the limits of the Sharia when they see graves, doing impermissible acts of Shirk and paganism at them, such as touching the grave, wiping oneself on it, kissing it, and other things mentioned in their proper place. Even if some pseudo-jurists who have no knowledge of the Book and Sunnah to illuminate their insights and hearts permit that, aligning with the common masses in their whims and justifying many of their misguidances for them. It truly pleased me that Dr. Al-Buti was not among them this time, for [96]

I saw him say in the etiquette of visiting his grave (peace and blessings be upon him) (p. 523): (So beware of rushing upon it or sticking to the windows or wiping over them as many ignorant people do, for that is an innovation (Bid'ah) that is close to being prohibited). This statement from the Doctor, despite the hesitation it contains regarding the ruling of what was mentioned - which indicates he has not yet understood his saying (peace and blessings be upon him): (Every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire) - indicates clearly that he cannot believe that Bilal rubbed his face on the Prophet's grave (peace and blessings be upon him). This is the truth. In that case, how does the Doctor use this narration of Ibn Asakir as proof when it contains this Munkar (denounced act) by his own admission? The truth is that the Doctor does not want verification; if he wanted it, he could not achieve it because he does not possess the means enabling him to do so. He takes from a single narration what he desires and uses it as proof, and turns away from what he does not desire, rather he denies it. Otherwise, what would the Doctor say to one of the innovators or pseudo-jurists who might argue against him using this narration of Ibn Asakir for the permissibility of rubbing oneself on the Noble Grave, when he himself has used it as proof and strengthened it?

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: 3 - His saying: (The young women came out of their private quarters...) etc., is poetic, imaginative speech whose fabrication is apparent. Otherwise, what is the connection between their coming out and hearing the second testimony and their saying (Has the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, been sent [resurrected])? Because of that, Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar asserted that this story is fabricated, as will come. Second: Al-Buti's saying: (Ibn Asakir narrated it with a Jayyid [good] chain). I say: In it are two criticisms: The first: That this classification of 'Jayyid' is not from the Doctor's knowledge or Ijtihad, because he has absolutely no knowledge qualifying him to issue such a judgment, as the readers have known from the previous articles. Even if this judgment is an error in itself as will come, it was obligatory upon him to attribute it to the one he copied it from, so as not to appear satiated with what is not his, due to his saying (peace and blessings be upon him): (The one who pretends to satisfy himself with what he was not given is like the wearer of two garments of falsehood). Agreed upon. [97]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: The second: The mentioned statement belongs to Sheikh As-Subki the Shafi'i; he said it in his book (Shifa' As-Siqam fi Ziyarat Khayr Al-Anam). The verifying Hafiz Muhammad ibn Abdul-Hadi Al-Hanbali refuted him in his great book: (As-Sarim Al-Munki fi Ar-Radd 'ala As-Subki) (pp. 210-215). He wrote at length on it, the summary of which is that its chain is not fit to be relied upon, nor is it referred to in disputes by any of the Imams of this field. I will explain its defect shortly, Allah the Exalted willing. Is the Doctor aware of this, yet preferred As-Subki's saying over it for no reason other than that he is Shafi'i in Madhhab like him? Or did he not know of it at all? The matter is as was said: If you do not know... The third: That the chain of the story is as far as can be from being 'Jayyid'. For it is in Ibn Asakir, as previously mentioned, from the narration of Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Sulayman from his father Sulayman ibn Bilal. This is a dark chain containing two unknowns: The first: Sulayman ibn Bilal. Al-Hafiz Ibn Abdul-Hadi said: (He is unknown; rather, he is Majhul al-Hal (unknown state) [sic: Original text], narrating little, not famous for bearing knowledge or transmitting it, and no Imam authenticated him as far as we know. Al-Bukhari did not mention his biography in his book, nor did Ibn Abi Hatim, and no hearing from Umm Darda' is known for him). I say: He is Majhul al-Ayn (unknown person). What is in the original (Majhul al-Hal) is perhaps a typo or a slip of the pen from the author, may Allah have mercy on him. Following Al-Bukhari and Ibn Abi Hatim, Adh-Dhahabi did not mention him in (Al-Mizan) nor Al-Hafiz in (Al-Lisan). The other: Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn Bilal. Al-Hafiz Ibn Abdul-Hadi said (A sheikh not known for trustworthiness or honesty, nor accuracy or probity. Rather, he is unknown, not known for transmission nor famous for narration. No one narrated from him other than Muhammad ibn Al-Fayd. He narrated from him this Munkar report). Adh-Dhahabi listed him in (Ad-Du'afa) and said: (He is not known). And he said in (Al-Mizan): (There is ignorance [Jahala] regarding him; Muhammad ibn Al-Fayd Al-Ghassani narrated from him). [98]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar approved him in (Al-Lisan) and added to it saying: (Ibn Asakir gave his biography then cited his narration from his father from his grandfather from Umm Darda' from Abu Darda' regarding the story of Bilal's journey to Sham and the story of his coming to Medina and his Adhan there and Medina shaking with weeping because of that. It is a story of clear fabrication). I say: Both Hafiz Al-Mizzi and Ibn Kathir pointed to the weakness of this story. As for the first, it is in the biography of Bilal in his book (Tahdhib al-Kamal), and the other in his biography in his book (Al-Bidaya) (2/102). So these are five famous Huffaz - all of them Shafi'is to Al-Buti's luck, except Ibn Abdul-Hadi - who asserted its lack of authenticity, ranging from explicitly declaring it fabricated to weakening it. Opposing them is As-Subki alone who declared its chain 'Jayyid'. Scientific criticism decidedly judges him to be deluded, if not said to be following his whim. Despite this, the virtuous Doctor imitated him excluding the others. So what does every unbiased person stripped of whim say about this Doctor who authors books on Seerah and determines Sharia rulings while he does not know how to follow evidence nor how to imitate [correctly]? O Allah, guide him. Two notices: First: Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn Bilal was given a biography by Al-Hafiz Ibn Abdul-Hadi (p. 224) from which it is taken that he is Majhul al-Hal. However, I found Ibn Abi Hatim narrated in (Al-Jarh wat-Ta'dil) (3/2/267) from his father that he said about him: (There is no harm in his Hadith). Thus, I avoided defecting the story through him as well. The other: Al-Buti cited Ibn Asakir's previous narration regarding Bilal, arguing with it against Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, regarding his opposition - according to Al-Buti's claim - to the consensus stating the legitimacy of visiting his grave (peace and blessings be upon him). This is a fabrication against Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him. Its banner was carried by Sheikh Al-Akhna'i, As-Subki, and others of old, and Zayni Dahlan and his likes in his war against the renewer of the call of Tawhid, Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab, may Allah's mercy be upon him, and those who followed them in it from the earlier and later generations, including the poor Al-Buti. For he said (p. 520): [99]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: (And know that visiting his mosque and his grave, peace and blessings be upon him, is among the greatest acts of closeness to Allah Almighty. The masses of Muslims have agreed on that in every era until our day. No one disagreed in that except Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah forgive him, for he held that visiting his grave is not legitimate). Then he argued for the mentioned consensus with four faces, one of which is Ibn Asakir's narration. Then he said: (Know that there is no basis for what Ibn Taymiyyah was unique in, regarding his rejection of these faces without a repeller, and the saying that visiting his grave, peace and blessings be upon him, is not legitimate). I say: This is a lie and a great fabrication by this pretender against Sheikh al-Islam, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him. His books and fatwas are overflowing with explicit statements on the legitimacy of visiting Muslim graves in general and visiting his grave (peace and blessings be upon him) in particular, as is known to anyone who viewed any of the Sheikh's books and studied them. Among that is his book (Ar-Radd 'ala Al-Akhna'i), who is one of the Sheikh's contemporaries who refuted him with injustice coupled with fabrication against him. From that is the accusation that Al-Buti snatched from him or from the likes of him among the fabricating liars without referring to some of the Sheikh's books to clarify the truth of the matter. For the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, said in the beginning of (Ar-Radd 'ala Al-Akhna'i) after mentioning his stated fabrication against him: (The respondent [meaning himself] is known to have books and fatwas filled with the recommendation of visiting graves. In all his rites [Manasik], he mentions the recommendation of visiting the graves of the people of Baqi' and the martyrs of Uhud, and mentions visiting the grave of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, when entering his mosque, and the etiquette in that). He said in the beginning of his book (Al-Jawab Al-Bahir fi Zuwwar Al-Maqabir) (p. 14): (I mentioned in what I wrote of rites that traveling to his mosque and visiting his grave, as the Imams of Muslims mention in the rites of Hajj, is a righteous recommended deed. I mentioned the Sunnah in that and how to greet him, and whether to face the chamber or the Qiblah, on two opinions...). Ibn Abdul-Hadi explained this in his refutation of As-Subki, so let whoever wants more refer to it. So what does the speaker say about Dr. Al-Buti and this fabrication of his? Did he not view [100]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
these sources that stand between him and it? Or did he view them and know that Sheikh al-Islam is innocent of it, then persisted in accusing him of it due to the rancor and hatred in his heart against Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah specifically and the Salafis generally, unconcerned with the likes of His saying, Exalted is He: {Indeed, those who came with falsehood are a group among you. Do not think it bad for you; rather it is good for you. For every person among them is what [punishment] he has earned from the sin} and His saying Almighty: {And those who harm believing men and believing women for [something] other than what they have earned have certainly born upon themselves a slander and manifest sin}. Whether it was this or that, Allah Almighty is the Reckoner of Al-Buti and his likes. We only have to defend those who believed and clear their arena from what they were accused of regarding lies and falsehoods, the motive for which is sometimes ignorance and other times injustice, and they may be combined. Of the first type is his saying (No one disagreed in that except Ibn Taymiyyah). For it is clear that the demonstrative noun (that) refers to both visiting his mosque (peace and blessings be upon him) and visiting his grave. This is a new fabrication in which Al-Buti was unique over his predecessors pointed to, because visiting his mosque (peace and blessings be upon him) is something Sheikh al-Islam also says is legitimate; rather, he says it is legitimate to travel to it specifically as previously mentioned, unlike traveling to visit his grave (peace and blessings be upon him) specifically. The apparent meaning of Al-Buti's speech is that he does not distinguish between the two visits like his previous predecessors. Evidence for that is his saying following what was quoted from him just now: (The sum of what Ibn Taymiyyah relied upon in that is the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: (Do not saddle the mounts except to three mosques...). This was used by Ibn Taymiyyah to prove the legitimacy of traveling to the mosque to the exclusion of the grave. Al-Buti rejects his deduction by claiming that the Hadith is a metonymy for the fact that the places most worthy of attention to travel to from far distances are these three mosques, evidenced by the fact that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) used to single out other places besides these mosques for visiting (), like his visit (peace and blessings be upon him) to Quba Mosque every week. So contemplate how he confuses visiting with travel [Shadd ar-Rihal], which is what is negated in the first Hadith, and visiting without travel [from afar], which is affirmed in the Hadith of Quba. There is no contradiction between them as is apparent. This is what [101]

Sheikh al-Islam went to, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, because he asserts the legitimacy of visiting Quba Mosque and visiting the graves of Baqi' and the martyrs and other graves, but he does not permit traveling [specifically] to them, as indicated by the first Hadith. So he asserts both Hadiths, whereas Al-Buti - may Allah guide him - does not have the knowledge to reconcile them if they were contradictory - except by suspending the indication of the first of them by claiming it is a metonymy. This is contrary to what the Predecessors (Salaf) among the Companions and others understood. It is established from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) that he forbade a man who wanted to go to At-Tur, saying to him: (Leave At-Tur alone and do not go to it). He argued against him with the Hadith prohibiting saddling the mounts. Similar to this is established from more than one Companion, as you see detailed in my book (Ahkam al-Jana'iz) (pp. 224-231). If the Hadith meant what Al-Buti went to, Ibn Umar's prohibition of going to At-Tur would not be sound. Do you think Al-Buti is correct or Ibn Umar? O Allah, guide him. My purpose now is not to discuss Al-Buti in everything that appeared in this issue regarding confusions, for this has another place which was previously referred to in explaining Fiqh errors - and how many they are. Rather, it is only to alert to his fabrication against Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah and to warn the readers not to be deceived by the likes of him. Allah the Exalted is the One asked to guide our steps, purify our intentions, and grant us success for righteous deeds in accordance with the Book and Sunnah.
