text: 15 - Then the Doctor said in the footnote of (p. 521): (There is also a group of Hadiths reported from him (peace and blessings be upon him) regarding the merit of visiting his grave; most of them are not free from weak or lenient status. Although they rise in their aggregate to the degree of strength, we preferred not to cite them with these proofs we mentioned so that the opposers do not cling to what they might like to cling to regarding leniency or weakness in them, thereby finding a loophole to support Ibn Taymiyyah's opinion despite its oddity). I say: This reminded me of the famous proverb: More foolish than an ostrich. [102]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: This is because if it sees the hunter, it buries its head in the sand so the hunter doesn't see it, due to its foolishness. So it is with the Doctor; by preferring not to cite those Hadiths, he imagined he would escape criticism and the exposure of error. But he is not escaping, for the referenced Hadiths are known for weakness and Nakarah (denouncement) whether he cites them or not. Had he truly wanted escape, he would have dispensed with this footnote and not blackened his book with it, nor opened the door of criticism upon himself. But Allah the Exalted refuses except to complete His light and show people the clear truth, and that one should not undertake this noble science [without qualification] so that they are not deceived by the author and his book again and stray from the straight path. It seems that what forced him to this statement is his feeling of ignorance and inability to prove what he claimed of strength. So he had no choice but the claim which no ignorant person is incapable of, and he was not satisfied with it until he resorted to justifying it with what makes the bereaved mother laugh. Not only this, but he turned away from the explicit statements of the Imams weakening all paths of the referenced Hadiths, among them a group of senior Shafi'i Imams whom the Doctor usually is fanatical for, like Imam An-Nawawi and Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani, let alone other verifying Huffaz. As I will explain, by the permission of Allah the Exalted, detailing what is in his statement of ignorance, feigning ignorance, fabrication, blind imitation, and following whim. He imitated in his claim that the Hadith of the merit of visiting his grave (peace and blessings be upon him) rises to the degree of strength some of the late imitator jurists who have no knowledge of this noble science, like Al-Akhna'i and As-Subki and others of the later ones. He knows that those who refuted them among the people of knowledge of this science explained the falsehood of the mentioned claim in a way that leaves no doubt. Here is Al-Akhna'i saying: (Hadiths were reported regarding visiting his grave, some Sahih and others which did not reach the degree of Sahih, but it is permissible to use them as evidence for Sharia rulings and preponderance is achieved by them). Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah refuted that against him with points, some of which concern us. He said, may Allah have mercy on him (p. 87), as if refuting Al-Buti due to the similarity between him and Al-Akhna'i: [103]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: (Third) That it is a saying for which he mentioned no proof. If it is said to him: We do not concede that a Sahih Hadith was reported regarding that, he needs to answer. He mentioned none of those Hadiths, so what he mentioned remains a bare claim met with denial. (The fourth face) That we say: This is a false saying not said by anyone of the Muslim scholars who know the Sahih. Among the Hadiths narrated with the wording: 'visiting his grave', there is no Sahih Hadith according to the people of knowledge. The masters of Sahih did not extract any of that, nor the masters of the relied-upon Sunan like Sunan Abi Dawud, An-Nasa'i, At-Tirmidhi and their likes, nor the people of Musnads of this genre like Musnad Ahmad and others, nor in Muwatta' Malik nor Musnad Ash-Shafi'i and the like. No Imam of the Muslims Imams like Abu Hanifa, Malik, Ash-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and others used as proof a Hadith containing the mention of visiting his grave. So how can there be Sahih Hadiths regarding that when none of the Imams of religion nor scholars of Hadith knew them? And from where does this one and his likes get that those Hadiths are Sahih when he does not know this field? (The fifth face) His saying: 'And others which did not reach the degree of Sahih...' We say to him: We do not concede that anything was reported of that which is permissible to use as evidence, and he mentioned only a bare claim, so it is met with denial. (The sixth face) That it be said: There is nothing in this chapter permissible to use as evidence; rather, they are all weak, nay fabricated, as detailed in places. I mentioned these Hadiths and mentioned the Imams' speech on them, Hadith by Hadith. Rather, I do not know of anyone of the Companions who spoke with the phrase 'visiting his grave' (peace and blessings be upon him) at all. So this phrase was not known among them; for this reason, Malik disliked speaking with it (1), unlike the word 'visiting' (Ziyarah) absolutely [for graves in general], for this word is known from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and his Companions...).

text: I say: So what diverted Dr. Al-Buti from relying on this speech of Sheikh al-Islam, who is more knowledgeable than As-Subki and others whom Al-Buti imitates in a way that comparison between them is invalid? Just as Malik asserts the dislike of speaking of 'visiting his grave' (peace and blessings be upon him), let alone other Imams of Hadith as will come. Were it not for whim and fear of being called 'Wahhabi'? Or is it that the Doctor, due to his narrow scope and lack of reading, has no knowledge of this viewpoint of Ibn Taymiyyah and the statements of scholars agreeing with him? This is something I consider unlikely. Whether it is this or that, the sweeter of them is bitter. Likewise, what prevented him from benefiting from the critique of Al-Hafiz Muhammad ibn Abdul-Hadi against Sheikh As-Subki in his book (As-Sarim Al-Munki fi Ar-Radd 'ala As-Subki)? He tracked As-Subki's Hadiths on Ziyarah Hadith by Hadith and explained their defects and the sayings of Imams of Hadith regarding them from (p. 10 - 171), detailing the speech in a way that leaves no doubt in the heart of any fair person regarding their weakness and the non-establishment of anything from them at all, and that there is nothing in them that strengthens each other due to the severity of their weakness, the disturbance of their chains, and the contradiction of their wordings. Therefore, I see it as obligatory upon me to summarize the discussion on them here to the extent that reveals their defects and establishes the proof against Al-Buti and his likes among the imitators and those deceived by them {so that those who perished [through disbelief] would perish upon evidence}, referring whoever wants detail to the book of Al-Hafiz Ibn Abdul-Hadi, for he collected and encompassed, and the book At-Talkhis by Ibn Hajar (Vol 2 / 266 & 267), and to my book (Silsilat Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah wal-Mawdu'ah), for I expanded the discussion in it on some of them, numbers (25, 47, and 204). The First Hadith: From Ibn Umar, Marfu' with the wording: (Whoever visits my grave, my intercession is obligatory for him). It has paths from him: The first: From the narration of Musa ibn Hilal Al-Abdi, who is unknown (Majhul). He was disturbed (Mudtarib) in its chain; once he said: from Abdullah ibn Umar, and once: from Ubaydullah ibn Umar from Nafi' from him. Al-Bayhaqi said: [105]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: (Whether he said Ubaydullah or Abdullah, it is Munkar from Nafi' from Ibn Umar; no one else brought it). Al-Uqayli said about it: (His Hadith is not Sahih and is not corroborated). Then he cited it with his chain and said following it: (And regarding narration in this chapter, there is leniency). In Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar's quote from him, he said: (And nothing is authentic in this chapter). The meaning is one, which is that its paths are all weak. That is what Al-Hafiz explicitly stated at the end of his discussion on the Hadith. Ubaydullah - the diminutive - is trustworthy (Thiqah), unlike his brother Abdullah - the non-diminutive - for he is weak. Ibn Adi preferred that he is the owner of this Hadith, and Imam Ibn Khuzaymah agreed with him and explicitly stated that a trustworthy narrator does not narrate this Munkar report, as Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said. That is why An-Nawawi said: (Its chain is very weak). The second: From the narration of Abdullah ibn Ibrahim from Abdur-Rahman ibn Zaid ibn Aslam from his father from Ibn Umar. Abdullah ibn Ibrahim, who is Ibn Abi Amr Al-Ghafari, is accused of lying and fabrication. Similar to him is Abdur-Rahman ibn Zaid ibn Aslam, for he is very weak. He is the narrator of the Hadith of Adam (peace be upon him) seeking intercession by our Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), which is fabricated as I explained in (Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah) number (25). An-Nawawi said regarding this path as well: (Its chain is very weak). The third: From the narration of Maslamah ibn Salim Al-Juhani from Ubaydullah ibn Umar from Nafi' from Salim from him with the wording: (Whoever comes to me visiting, not driven by any need except visiting me, it is a right upon me to be an intercessor for him on the Day of Resurrection). Maslamah is unknown (Majhul). It is said of him Maslamah ibn Salim Al-Juhani. Abu Dawud said: He is not trustworthy. He was disturbed in its chain, narrating it once like this, and once saying: from Abdullah ibn Umar from Nafi'. This is most likely, that it is from his narration from Abdullah ibn Umar Al-Umari, the non-diminutive who is weakened. So this Juhani would be a follower/corroborator for Musa ibn Hilal who is in the first path. [106]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: However, his following him is something scholars do not rejoice at because he is not trustworthy as you knew. Even if it were useful, the Hadith would not be strengthened by it because above them is Abdullah ibn Umar the weak. Furthermore, it does not contain visiting the Noble Grave, so it can be interpreted as visiting him in his lifetime, and there is no doubt about the legitimacy of this. So be aware and do not be among the heedless people of whims. Moreover, what is preserved in this meaning is what Ayyub narrated from Nafi' from Ibn Umar who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: (Whoever among you can die in Medina, let him do so, for I will witness (or in a narration: intercede) for whoever dies in it). Extracted by Ahmad, At-Tirmidhi who authenticated it, Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih). This is the origin of the Hadith and its wording, but those unknown and weak narrators distorted it, intentionally or inadvertently, and those with no knowledge were deceived by them. The fourth: From the narration of Hafs ibn Sulayman Abu Umar from Al-Layth ibn Abi Sulaym from Mujahid from him with the wording: (Whoever performs Hajj and visits my grave after my death is like one who visited me in my life). Some added (and accompanied me). This is very Munkar. Hafs ibn Sulayman, the Asadi Qari Al-Ghadiri, is abandoned (Matruk), accused of lying and fabrication. He was unique with it as Al-Bayhaqi said. Layth ibn Abi Sulaym is weak and confused (Mukhtalit). It is extracted in (Ad-Da'ifah) number (47). The fifth: From the narration of Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn An-Nu'man ibn Shibl: My grandfather told me, saying: Malik told me from Nafi' from him with the wording: (Whoever performs Hajj to the House and does not visit me has shunned me). This is fabricated as stated by Ibn Al-Jawzi, Adh-Dhahabi, Az-Zarkashi and others, as you see in (Ad-Da'ifah) (4). The defect is from Muhammad ibn Muhammad or from his grandfather An-Nu'man ibn Shibl; both are accused. Ibn Abdul-Hadi preferred the first, so let whoever wishes refer to it. Also, it does not mention visiting the Noble Grave. The Second Hadith: From Umar, Marfu' with the wording: (Whoever visits my grave, or he said whoever visits me, I will be an intercessor or witness for him). Narrated by Sawwar ibn Maimun Abu Al-Jarrah Al-Abdi: A man from the family of Umar told me from him. This is a disturbed text and a dark chain. Sawwar is unknown (Majhul), not known. Some [107]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: narrators invert him saying: Maimun ibn Sawwar. His Sheikh is a man not named, who is in a worse state than the unknown. They were disturbed regarding him; some say: (a man from the family of Umar) as in this narration. Some say: (a man from the children of Hatib). Some insert between him and Sawwar: Harun ibn Qaza'ah, who is also unknown. Some say Harun ibn Abi Qaza'ah. Al-Uqayli, As-Saji, and Ibn Al-Jarud mentioned him in (Ad-Du'afa). Al-Bayhaqi said: (This is an unknown chain). The Third Hadith: From Ibn Abbas, Marfu' with the wording: (Whoever performs Hajj to Mecca then intends me in my mosque, two accepted Hajjs are written for him). This is fabricated; its defect is Usayd ibn Zaid Al-Jammal Al-Kufi. Ibn Ma'in said: (A liar, I heard him narrating lies). With that, it does not mention the grave at all. It has another path from him with the wording: (Whoever visits me after my death is like one who visited me in my life). And (Whoever visits me until he ends up at my grave, I will be a witness or he said intercessor for him on the Day of Resurrection). This is also fabricated. In its chain is Fadalah ibn Sa'id ibn Zumayl, unknown (Majhul), not known except in this report with which he was unique and was not corroborated. Adh-Dhahabi said: (This is fabricated). The Fourth Hadith: From Ali, Marfu': (Whoever visits my grave after my death, it is as if he visited me in my life. And whoever performs Hajj and does not visit my grave has shunned me). This is fabricated. Its defect is that it is from the narration of An-Nu'man ibn Shibl, previously mentioned. Al-Hafiz Musa ibn Harun Al-Hammal accused him. Ibn Hibban said: (He brings calamities from trustworthy narrators and inverted reports from established narrators). He narrates it from Muhammad ibn Al-Fadl ibn Atiyyah, who was a liar as Ibn Ma'in said. Ahmad said: His Hadith is the Hadith of the people of lying. He narrates this from Jabir Al-Ju'fi, who is a Rafidi, abandoned (Matruk), severely weak. Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, said: I have not seen anyone more lying than him. The Fifth Hadith: From Ibn Mas'ud, Marfu' with the wording: (Whoever performs the Hajj of Islam and visits my grave and fights in a Ghazwah and prays upon me in Bayt al-Maqdis [Jerusalem], Allah will not ask him about what He obligated upon him). This is a false Hadith, apparent in falsehood. That is why As-Suyuti and others said: It is a [108]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: fabricated Hadith. It is extracted in (Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah) number (204). The Sixth Hadith: From Abu Hurairah, Marfu': (Whoever visits me after my death, it is as if he visited me while I was alive). This is fabricated. In its chain is Khalid ibn Yazid Al-Umari. Ibn Ma'in and Abu Hatim said: (Liar). Ibn Hibban said: (He narrates fabrications from trustworthy narrators). I say: The chain to him is dark, containing those who are not known. The Seventh Hadith: From Anas, and it has two wordings via two paths: The first: With the wording: (Whoever visits me seeking reward, I will be a witness and intercessor for him on the Day of Resurrection). In its chain is Sulayman ibn Yazid Al-Ka'bi. Abu Hatim said: (Munkar al-Hadith). Then it is interrupted (Munqati') because this Al-Ka'bi did not hear from Anas. The other: With the wording: (There is no one of my Ummah who has means then does not visit me, except that he has no excuse). This is fabricated. In its chain is Sam'an ibn Al-Mahdi. Adh-Dhahabi said: (He is hardly known. A lied copy was attached to him which I saw; may Allah uglify the one who fabricated it). I say: And the chain to him is layers of darkness, one over another. It also does not mention the grave. The Eighth Hadith: From a man from Bukayr ibn Abdullah, Marfu': (Whoever comes to Medina visiting, my intercession is obligatory for him on the Day of Resurrection). This is false as Ibn Abdul-Hadi said. Its chain is Mursal or Mu'dal, and it contains the vague man. It does not mention the grave. I say: These are the Hadiths Dr. Al-Buti pointed to, and those are their paths which he claimed the Hadith rises by their aggregate to the degree of strength, without conducting any study on them - if he were capable of it - to know the severity of their weakness and the repulsion of their texts, which would prevent him from the mentioned claim. But if he is incapable of that study, does he not know how to imitate either? Instead of imitating Sheikh al-Islam who explicitly stated the weakening of the Hadith from all its paths as you saw, he imitates Al-Akhna'i. Or instead of imitating Imam An-Nawawi who [109]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text: greatly weakened its two preceding paths - which are its most famous paths - he imitated As-Subki who strengthened the Hadith contrary to everyone who spoke on the Hadith among those preceding him in knowledge and time, who asserted that it is a Munkar Hadith, like Ibn Khuzaymah, Al-Bayhaqi, and others who spoke on the individual paths, and Al-Asqalani, Adh-Dhahabi, and As-Suyuti, let alone Ibn Taymiyyah and Ibn Abdul-Hadi. If the Doctor knew how to imitate at least, he would have imitated these due to their specialization in this science, their large number, and their precedence. But Allah the Almighty spoke the truth: {And he for whom Allah has not appointed a light, for him there is no light}. My belief is that the Doctor thinks {And indeed, assumption avails not against the truth at all} that any Hadith whose paths are numerous is strengthened by them. This is ignorance contrary to what is established in the science of Hadith terminology. Ibn As-Salah said in (Al-Muqaddimah) (pp. 36-37) after mentioning the Hasan li-Ghayrihi Hadith, which is that which came from more than one face not containing a negligent narrator making many mistakes: (Perhaps the understanding researcher says: We find Hadiths judged as weak despite being narrated with many chains from numerous faces, like the Hadith (The ears are part of the head) and similar ones. Why did you not make that and its likes of the Hasan type because some of it supports others as you said regarding Hasan as previously mentioned? The answer to that is that not every weakness in Hadith is removed by its coming from [multiple] faces. Rather, that varies. There is a category where that [weakness] is removed, such as when its weakness arises from the poor memory of its narrator despite him being of the people of truthfulness and piety. If we see what he narrated has come from another face, we know that it is of what he memorized and his precision did not fail in it. Likewise, if its weakness is from the aspect of Irsaal (disconnection), it is removed by similar to that, as in the Mursal reported by a Hafiz Imam, for it has slight weakness removed by its narration from another face. And there is weakness not removed by similar to that due to the strength of the weakness and the inability of this restorer to restore it. That is like the weakness arising from the narrator being accused of lying or the Hadith being Shadh (anomalous). This is a summary whose details are perceived by practice and research, so know that, for it is of the precious gems). I say: Yes, by Allah, it is of the precious gems neglected by many who occupy themselves [110]

book_title: Difa' 'an al-Hadith an-Nabawi wa as-Seerah
text:
with this science, let alone others who have no knowledge of it at all, like this one whom we are in the process of refuting and warning against the effects of his ignorance. For that reason, when Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir summarized this speech of Ibn As-Salah in his (Mukhtasar) (p. 43) and approved it, Sheikh Ahmad Shakir, may Allah have mercy on him, commented on it saying: (From this, the error of many late scholars becomes clear in their absolute statement that the weak Hadith, if it comes from multiple weak paths, rises to the degree of Hasan or Sahih. For if the weakness of the Hadith is due to the wickedness (fisq) of the narrator or his being accused of lying, then it comes from other paths of this type, it increases in weakness. Because the uniqueness of those accused of lying or those wounded in their integrity, such that no one else narrates it, removes trust in their Hadith and confirms the weakness of their narration. This is clear). I say: If the reader examines closely those preceding paths of the Hadith of Ziyarah, he will not find in them any quality of those qualities mentioned by Ibn As-Salah regarding paths by which a Hadith is strengthened. There is not in them, for example, at least one narrator who is of the people of truthfulness known to have weak memory. Rather, they are among those accused of lying, or known for severe weakness, or unknowns, or vague individuals, along with the Hadith not being free from disturbance and Nakarah in the text. Also, there is no single Mursal path among them sent by a Hafiz Imam. Because of that, we find many weak Hadiths that scholars have asserted are weak even though they have many paths. Ibn As-Salah gave an example for that with the Hadith: (The ears are part of the head). I have a view on it from several aspects, the most important being that I found a strong chain for it, so I extracted it in (Sahih Abi Dawud) (123) and (Silsilat Al-Ahadith As-Sahihah) number (26); this is printed so let whoever wishes refer to it. Therefore, the better example in my view is the Hadith: (Whoever preserves for my Ummah forty Hadiths of the Sunnah, I will be an intercessor for him on the Day of Resurrection), as Al-Hafiz As-Sakhawi did in (Fath al-Mughith) (1/71). He said following it: (An-Nawawi reported the agreement of Huffaz on its weakness despite the multitude of its paths). Ignorance of this important rule leads to strengthening many weak Hadiths [111]

because of their paths. Rather, it may lead to joining some deviant sects. For example, this Hadith: (If you see Mu'awiyah on my pulpit, kill him). It was narrated from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id, Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, Jabir, Sahl ibn Hunayf, and others. Yet, it is counted among the fabricated Hadiths. Like it is the Hadith: (Ali is the best of mankind; whoever refuses has disbelieved). It has many paths as well. Examples of this type are very many, hardly countable. Refer if you wish to my book (Silsilat Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah), for there is much of it, including: (55, 133, 134, 139, 143 (52), 226, 230, 266, 332, 337, 451, 583, 585, 649...). I say: These examples of fabricated Hadiths should be authentic according to Dr. Al-Buti because his previous saying applies to them: (some of them strengthen others...) {So is there any who will remember}? In conclusion, I remind him of my advice which I offered to him coupled with citation of Imam An-Nawawi's speech shortly before this appendix, hoping that I will not be compelled again to waste time refuting his ignorances and fabrications. Asking the Mawla (Allah) Subhanahu wa Ta'ala to rectify our deeds, purify our intentions, and unite our hearts upon the Book of our Lord and the Sunnah of our Prophet. Indeed, He is Hearing, Responsive. Damascus 3 Rabi' Al-Awwal 1396.
